PLAYFF.TITLE: The Tragedy of Hamlet, Prince of Denmark

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Barnardo and Franciſco two Centinels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barnardo.
SPEECH.LINE: Who’s there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay anſwer me: Stand & vnfold
your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Long liue the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: He.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: You come moſt carefully vpon your houre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis now ſtrook twelue, get thee to bed Franciſco.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: For this releefe much thankes: ’Tis bitter cold,
And I am ſicke at heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you had quiet Guard?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a Mouſe ſtirring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, goodnight. If you do meet Horatio and
Marcellus, the Riuals of my Watch, bid them make haſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke I heare them. Stand: who’s there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Friends to this ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: And Leige-men to the Dane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fran.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue you good night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: O farwel honeſt Soldier, who hath relieu’d you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fra.
SPEECH.LINE: Barnardo ha’s my place: giue you goodnight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Holla Barnardo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Say, what is Horatio there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: A peece of him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome Horatio, welcome good Marcellus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: What, ha’s this thing appear’d againe to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſeene nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Horatio ſaies, ’tis but our Fantaſie,
And will not let beleefe take hold of him
Touching this dreaded ſight, twice ſeene of vs,
Therefore I haue intreated him along
With vs, to watch the minutes of this Night,
That if againe this Apparition come,
He may approue our eyes, and ſpeake to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Tuſh, tuſh, ’twill not appeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bar.
SPEECH.LINE: Sit downe a-while,
And let vs once againe aſſaile your eares,
That are ſo fortified againſt our Story,
What we two Nights haue ſeene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, ſit we downe,
And let vs heare Barnardo ſpeake of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: Laſt night of all,
When yond ſame Starre that’s Weſtward from the Pole
Had made his courſe t’illume that part of Heauen
Where now it burnes, Marcellus and my ſelfe,
The Bell then beating one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, breake thee of:
Looke where it comes againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: In the ſame figure, like the King that’s dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou art a Scholler; ſpeake to it Horatio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: Lookes it not like the King? Marke it Horatio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt like: It harrowes me with fear & wonder

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: It would be ſpoke too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Queſtion it Horatio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: What art thou that vſurp’ſt this time of night,
Together with that Faire and Warlike forme
In which the Maieſty of buried Denmarke
Did ſometimes march: By Heauen I charge thee ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: It is offended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: See, it ſtalkes away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay: ſpeake; ſpeake: I Charge thee, ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis gone, and will not anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Horatio? You tremble & look pale:
Is not this ſomething more then Fantaſie?
What thinke you on’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Before my God, I might not this beleeue
Without the ſenſible and true auouch
Of mine owne eyes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it not like the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: As thou art to thy ſelfe,
Such was the very Armour he had on,
When th’Ambitious Norwey combatted:
So frown’d he once, when in an angry parle
He ſmot the ſledded Pollax on the Ice.
’Tis ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Thus twice before, and iuſt at this dead houre,
With Martiall ſtalke, hath he gone by our Watch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: In what particular thought to work, I know not:
But in the groſſe and ſcope of my Opinion,
This boades ſome ſtrange erruption to our State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Good now ſit downe, & tell me he that knowes
Why this ſame ſtriƈt and moſt obſeruant Watch,
So nightly toyles the ſubieƈt of the Land,
And why ſuch dayly Caſt of Brazon Cannon
And Forraigne Mart for Implements of warre:
Why ſuch impreſſe of Ship-wrights, whoſe ſore Taske
Do’s not diuide the Sunday from the weeke,
What might be toward, that this ſweaty haſt
Doth make the Night ioynt-Labourer with the day:
Who is’t that can informe me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: That can I,
At leaſt the whiſper gœs ſo: Our laſt King,
Whoſe Image euen but now appear’d to vs,
Was (as you know) by Fortinbras of Norway,
(Thereto prick’d on by a moſt emulate Pride)
Dar’d to the Combate. In which, our Valiant Hamlet,
(For ſo this ſide of our knowne world eſteem’d him)
Did ſlay this Fortinbras: who by a Seal’d Compaƈt,
Well ratified by Law, and Heraldrie,
Did forfeite (with his life) all thoſe his Lands
Which he ſtood ſeiz’d on, to the Conqueror:
Againſt the which, a Moity competent
Was gaged by our King: which had return’d
To the Inheritance of Fortinbras,
Had he bin Vanquiſher, as by the ſame Cou’nant
And carriage of the Article deſigne,
His fell to Hamlet. Now ſir, young Fortinbras,
Of vnimproued Mettle, hot and full,
Hath in the ſkirts of Norway, heere and there,
Shark’d vp a Liſt of Landleſſe Reſolutes,
For Foode and Diet, to ſome Enterprize
That hath a ſtomacke in’t: which is no other
(And it doth well appeare vnto our State)
But to recouer of vs by ſtrong hand
And termes Compulſatiue, thoſe foreſaid Lands
So by his Father loſt: and this (I take it)
Is the maine Motiue of our Preparations,
The Sourſe of this our Watch, and the cheefe head
Of this poſt-haſt, and Romage in the Land.
But ſoft, behold: Lœ, where it comes againe:
Ile croſſe it, though it blaſt me. Stay Illuſion:
If thou haſt any ſound, or vſe of Voyce,
Speake to me. If there be any good thing to be done,
That may to thee do eaſe, and grace to me; ſpeak to me.
If thou art priuy to thy Countries Fate
(Which happily foreknowing may auoyd) Oh ſpeake.
Or, if thou haſt vp-hoorded in thy life
Extorted Treaſure in the wombe of Earth,
(For which, they ſay, you Spirits oft walke in death)
Speake of it. Stay, and ſpeake. Stop it Marcellus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I ſtrike at it with my Partizan?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Do, if it will not ſtand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis gone.
We do it wrong, being ſo Maieſticall
To offer it the ſhew of Violence,
For it is as the Ayre, invulnerable,
And our vaine blowes, malicious Mockery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Barn.
SPEECH.LINE: It was about to ſpeake, when the Cocke crew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: And then it ſtarted, like a guilty thing
Vpon a fearfull Summons. I haue heard,
The Cocke that is the Trumpet to the day,
Doth with his lofty and ſhrill-sounding Throate
Awake the God of Day: and at his warning,
Whether in Sea, or Fire, in Earth, or Ayre,
Th’extrauagant, and erring Spirit, hyes
To his Confine. And of the truth heerein,
This preſent Obieƈt made probation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: It faded on the crowing of the Cocke.
Some ſayes, that euer ’gainſt that Seaſon comes
Wherein our Sauiours Birch is celebrated,
The Bird of Dawning ſingeth all night long:
And then (they ſay) no Spirit can walke abroad,
The nights are wholſome, then no Planets ſtrike,
No Faiery talkes, nor Witch hath power to Charme:
So hallow’d, and ſo gracious is the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: So haue I heard, and do in part beleeue it.
But looke, the Morne in Ruſſet mantle clad,
Walkes o’re the dew of yon high Eaſterne Hill,
Breake we our Watch vp, and by my aduice
Let vs impart what we haue ſeene to night
Vnto yong Hamlet. For vpon my life,
This Spirit dumbe to vs, will ſpeake to him:
Do you conſent we ſhall acquaint him with it,
As needfull in our Loues, fitting our Duty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Let do’t I pray, and I this morning know
Where we ſhall finde him moſt conueniently.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Claudius King of Denmarke, Gertrude the Queene, Hamlet, Polonius, Lærtes, and his Siſter Ophelia, Lords Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Though yet of Hamlet our deere Brothers death
The memory be greene: and that it vs befitted
To beare our hearts in greefe, and our whole Kingdome
To be contraƈted in one brow of wœ:
Yet ſo farre hath Diſcretion fought with Nature,
That we with wiſeſt ſorrow thinke on him,
Together with remembrance of our ſelues.
Therefore our ſometimes Siſter, now our Queene,
Th’imperiall Ioyntreſſe of this warlike State,
Haue we, as ’twere, with a defeated ioy,
With one Auſpicious, and one Dropping eye,
With mirth in Funerall, and with Dirge in Marriage,
In equall Scale weighing Delight and Dole
Taken to Wife; nor haue we heerein barr’d
Your better Wiſedomes, which haue freely gone
With this affaire along, for all our Thankes.
Now followes, that you know young Fortinbras,
Holding a weake ſuppoſall of our worth;
Or thinking by our late deere Brothers death,
Our State to be diſioynt, and out of Frame,
Colleagued with the dreame of his Aduantage;
He hath not fayl’d to peſter vs with Meſſage,
Importing the ſurrender of thoſe Lands
Loſt by his Father: with all Bonds of Law
To our moſt valiant Brother. So much for him.
Now for our ſelfe, and for this time of meeting
Thus much the buſineſſe is. We haue heere writ
To Norway, Vncle of young Fortinbras,
Who Impotent and Bedrid, ſcarſely heares
Of this his Nephewes purpoſe, to ſuppreſſe
His further gate heerein. In that the Leuies,
The Liſts, and full proportions are all made
Out of his ſubieƈt: and we heere diſpatch
You good Cornelius, and you Voltemand,
For bearing of this greeting to old Norway,
Giuing to you no further perſonall power
To buſineſſe with the King, more then the ſcope
Of theſe dilated Articles allow:
Farewell, and let your haſt commend your duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volt.
SPEECH.LINE: In that, and all things, will we ſhew our duty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: We doubt it nothing, heartily farewell.
And now Lærtes, what’s the newes with you?
You told vs of ſome ſuite. What is’t Lærtes?
You cannot ſpeake of Reaſon to the Dane,
And looſe your voyce. What would’ſt thou beg Lærtes,
That ſhall not be my Offer, not thy Asking?
The Head is not more Natiue to the Heart,
The Hand more inſtrumentall to the Mouth,
Then is the Throne of Denmarke to thy Father.
What would’ſt thou haue Lærtes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Dread my Lord,
Your leaue and fauour to returne to France,
From whence, though willingly I came to Denmarke
To ſhew my duty in your Coronation,
Yet now I muſt confeſſe, that duty done,
My thoughts and wiſhes bend againe towards France,
And bow them to your gracious leaue and pardon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you your Fathers leaue?
What ſayes Pollonius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath my Lord:
I do beſeech you giue him leaue to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Take thy faire houre Lærtes, time be thine,
And thy beſt graces ſpend it at thy will:
But now my Coſin Hamlet, and my Sonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A little more then kin, and leſſe then kinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: How is it that the Clouds ſtill hang on you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo my Lord, I am too much i’th’Sun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Hamlet caſt thy nightly colour off,
And let thine eye looke like a Friend on Denmarke.
Do not for euer with thy veyled lids
Seeke for thy Noble Father in the duſt;
Thou know’ſt ’tis common, all that liues muſt dye,
Paſſing through Nature, to Eternity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I Madam, it is common.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be;
Why ſeemes it ſo particular with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Seemes Madam? Nay, it is: I know not Seemes:
’Tis not alone my Inky Cloake (good Mother)
Nor Cuſtomary ſuites of ſolemne Blacke,
Nor windy ſuſpiration of forc’d breath,
No, nor the fruitfull Riuer in the Eye,
Nor the deieƈted hauiour of the Viſage,
Together with all Formes, Moods, ſhewes of Griefe,
That can denote me truly. Theſe indeed Seeme,
For they are aƈtions that a man might play:
But I haue that Within, which paſſeth ſhow;
Theſe, but the Trappings, and the Suites of wœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis ſweet and commendable
In your Nature Hamlet,
To giue theſe mourning duties to your Father:
But you muſt know, your Father loſt a Father,
That Father loſt, loſt his, and the Suruiuer bound
In filiall Obligation, for ſome terme
To do obſequious Sorrow. But to perſeuer
In obſtinate Condolement, is a courſe
Of impious ſtubbornneſſe. ’Tis vnmanly greefe,
It ſhewes a will moſt incorreƈt to Heauen,
A Heart vnfortified, a Minde impatient,
An Vnderſtanding ſimple, and vnſchool’d:
For, what we know muſt be, and is as common
As any the moſt vulgar thing to ſence,
Why ſhould we in our peeuiſh Oppoſition
Take it to heart? Fye, ’tis a fault to Heauen,
A fault againſt the Dead, a fault to Nature,
To Reaſon moſt abſurd, whoſe common Theame
Is death of Fathers, and who ſtill hath cried,
From the firſt Coarſe, till he that dyed to day,
This muſt be ſo. We pray you throw to earth
This vnpreuayling wœ, and thinke of vs
As of a Father; For let the world take note,
You are the moſt immediate to our Throne,
And with no leſſe Nobility of Loue,
Then that which deereſt Father beares his Sonne,
Do I impart towards you. For your intent
In going backe to Schoole in Wittenberg,
It is moſt retrograde to our deſire:
And we beſeech you, bend you to remaine
Heere in the cheere and comfort of our eye,
Our cheefeſt Courtier Coſin, and our Sonne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Let not thy Mother loſe her Prayers Hamlet:
I prythee ſtay with vs, go not to Wittenberg.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall in all my beſt
Obey you Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ’tis a louing, and a faire Reply,
Be as our ſelfe in Denmarke. Madam come,
This gentle and vnforc’d accord of Hamlet
Sits ſmiling to my heart; in grace whereof,
No iocond health that Denmarke drinkes to day,
But the great Cannon to the Clowds ſhall tell,
And the Kings Rouce, the Heauens ſhall bruite againe,
Reſpeaking earthly Thunder. Come away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh that this too too ſolid Fleſh, would melt,
Thaw, and reſolue it ſelfe into a Dew:
Or that the Euerlaſting had not fixt
His Cannon ’gainſt Selfe-ſlaughter. O God, O God!
How weary, ſtale, flat, and vnprofitable
Seemes to me all the vſes of this world?
Fie on’t? Oh fie, fie, ’tis an vnweeded Garden
That growes to Seed: Things rank, and groſſe in Nature
Poſſeſſe it meerely. That it ſhould come to this:
But two months dead: Nay, not ſo much; not two,
So excellent a King, that was to this
Hiperion to a Satyre: ſo louing to my Mother,
That he might not beteene the windes of heauen
Viſit her face too roughly. Heauen and Earth
Muſt I remember: why ſhe would hang on him,
As if encreaſe of Appetite had growne
By what is fed on; and yet within a month?
Let me not thinke on’t: Frailty, thy name is woman.
A little Month, or ere thoſe ſhoœs were old,
With which ſhe followed my poore Fathers body
Like Niobe, all teares. Why ſhe, euen ſhe.
(O Heauen! A beaſt that wants diſcourſe of Reaſon
Would haue mourn’d longer) married with mine Vnkle,
My Fathers Brother: but no more like my Father,
Then I to Hercules. Within a Moneth?
Ere yet the ſalt of moſt vnrighteous Teares
Had left the fluſhing of her gauled eyes,
She married. O moſt wicked ſpeed, to poſt
With ſuch dexterity to Inceſtuous ſheets:
It is not, nor it cannot come to good.
But breake my heart, for I muſt hold my tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Haile to your Lordſhip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad to ſee you well:
Horatio, or I do forget my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſame my Lord,
And your poore Seruant euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir my good friend,
Ile change that name with you:
And what make you from Wittenberg Horatio?
Marcellus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: My good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I am very glad to ſee you: good euen Sir.
But what in faith make you from Wittemberge?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: A truant diſpoſition, good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I would not haue your Enemy ſay ſo;
Nor ſhall you dœ mine eare that violence,
To make it truſter of your owne report
Againſt your ſelfe. I know you are no Truant:
But what is your affaire in Elſenour?
Wee’l teach you to drinke deepe, ere you depart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I came to ſee your Fathers Funerall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee dœ not mock me (fellow Student)
I thinke it was to ſee my Mothers Wedding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed my Lord, it followed hard vpon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Thrift thrift Horatio: the Funerall Bakt-meats
Did coldly furniſh forth the Marriage Tables;
Would I had met my deareſt fœ in heauen,
Ere I had euer ſeene that day Horatio.
My father, me thinkes I ſee my father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh where my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: In my minds eye (Horatio)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſaw him once; he was a goodly King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: He was a man, take him for all in all:
I ſhall not look vpon his like againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I thinke I ſaw him yeſternight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Saw? Who?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, the King your Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The King my Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Seaſon your admiration for a while
With an attent eare; till I may deliuer
Vpon the witneſſe of theſe Gentlemen,
This maruell to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: For Heauens loue let me heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Two nights together, had theſe Gentlemen
(Marcellus and Barnardo) on their Watch
In the dead waſt and middle of the night
Beene thus encountred. A figure like your Father,
Arm’d at all points exaƈtly, Cap a Pe,
Appeares before them, and with ſollemne march
Gœs ſlow and ſtately: By them thrice he walkt,
By their oppreſt and feare-ſurprized eyes,
Within his Truncheons length; whilſt they beſtil’d
Almoſt to Ielly with the Aƈt of feare,
Stand dumbe and ſpeake not to him. This to me
In dreadfull ſecrecie impart they did,
And I with them the third Night kept the Watch,
Whereas they had deliuer’d both in time,
Forme of the thing; each word made true and good,
The Apparition comes. I knew your Father:
Theſe hands are not more like.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: But where was this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord vpon the platforme where we watcht.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you not ſpeake to it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I did;
But anſwere made it none: yet once me thought
It lifted vp it head, and did addreſſe
It ſelfe to motion, like as it would ſpeake:
But euen then, the Morning Cocke crew lowd;
And at the ſound it ſhrunke in haſt away,
And vaniſht from our ſight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis very ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: As I dœ liue my honourd Lord ’tis true;
And we did thinke it writ downe in our duty
To let you know of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, indeed Sirs; but this troubles me.
Hold you the watch to Night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: We dœ my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Arm’d, ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Arm’d, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: From top to tœ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, from head to foote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then ſaw you not his face?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: O yes, my Lord, he wore his Beauer vp.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What, lookt he frowningly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: A countenance more in ſorrow then in anger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Pale, or red?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay very pale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: And fixt his eyes vpon you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt conſtantly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I would I had beene there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: It would haue much amaz’d you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Very like, very like: ſtaid it long?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: While one with moderate haſt might tell a hundred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Longer, longer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Not when I ſaw’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: His Beard was griſly? no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: It was, as I haue ſeene it in his life,
A Sable Siluer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile watch to Night; perchance ’twill wake againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant you it will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: If it aſſume my noble Fathers perſon,
Ile ſpeake to it, though Hell it ſelfe ſhould gape
And bid me hold my peace. I pray you all,
If you haue hitherto conceald this ſight;
Let it bee treble in your ſilence ſtill:
And whatſœuer els ſhall hap to night,
Giue it an vnderſtanding but no tongue;
I will requite your loues; ſo fare ye well:
Vpon the Platforme twixt eleuen and twelue,
Ile viſit you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Our duty to your Honour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Your loue, as mine to you: farewell.
My Fathers Spirit in Armes? All is not well:
I doubt ſome foule play: would the Night were come;
Till then ſit ſtill my ſoule; foule deeds will riſe,
Though all the earth orewhelm them to mens eies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: My neceſſaries are imbark’t; Farewell:
And Siſter,as the Winds giue Benefit,
And Conuoy is aſſiſtant; dœ not ſleepe,
But let me heare from you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophel.
SPEECH.LINE: Dœ you doubt that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: For Hamlet, and the trifling of his fauours,
Hold it a faſhion and a toy in Bloud;
A Violet in the youth of Primy Nature;
Froward,not permanent; ſweet not laſting
The ſuppliance of a minute? No more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophel.
SPEECH.LINE: No more but ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Thinke it no more:
For nature creſſant dœs not grow alone,
In thewes and Bulke: but as his Temple waxes,
The inward ſeruice of the Minde and Soule
Growes wide withall. Perhaps he loues you now,
And now no ſoyle nor cautell doth beſmerch
The vertue of his feare: but you muſt feare
His greatneſſe weigh’d, his will is not his owne;
For hee himſelfe is ſubieƈt to his Birth:
Hee may not, as vnuallued perſons dœ,
Carue for himſelfe; for, on his choyce depends
The ſanƈtity and health of the weole State.
And therefore muſt his choyce be circumſcrib’d
Vnto the voyce and yeelding of that Body,
Whereof he is the Head. Then if he ſayes he loues you,
It fits your wiſedome ſo farre to beleeue it;
As he in his peculiar Seƈt and force
May giue his ſaying deed: which is no further,
Then the maine voyce of Denmarke gœs withall.
Then weight what loſſe your Honour may ſuſtaine,
If with too credent eare you liſt his Songs;
Or loſe your Heart; or your chaſt Treaſure open
To his vnmaſtred importunity.
Feare it Ophelia,feare it my deare Siſter,
And keepe within the reare of your Affeƈtion;
Out of the ſhot and danger of Deſire.
The charieſt Maid is Prodigall enough,
If ſhe vnmaske her beauty to the Moone:
Vertue it ſelfe ſcapes not calumnious ſtroakes,
The Canker Galls, the Infants of the Spring
Too oft before the buttons be diſclos’d,
And in the Morne and liquid dew of Youth,
Contagious blaſtments are moſt imminent.
Be wary then, beſt ſafety lies in feare;
Youth to it ſelfe rebels, though none elſe neere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall th’effeƈt of this good Leſſon keepe,
As watchmen to my heart: but good my Brother
Dœ not as ſome vngracious Paſtors dœ,
Shew me the ſteepe and thorny way to Heauen;
Whilſt like a puft and reckleſſe Libertine
Himſelfe, the Primroſe path of dalliance treads,
And reaks not his owne reade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh, feare me not.
I ſtay too long; but here my Father comes:
A double bleſſing is a double grace;
Occaſion ſmiles vpon a ſecond leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet heere Lærtes? Aboord, aboord for ſhame,
The winde ſits in the ſhoulder of your ſaile,
And you are ſtaid for there: my bleſſing with you;
And theſe few Precepts in thy memory,
See thou Charaƈter. Giue thy thoughts no tongue,
Nor any vnproportion’d thoughts his Aƈt:
Be thou familiar; but by no meanes vulgar:
The friends thou haſt, and their adoption tride,
Grapple them to thy Soule, with hoopes of Steele:
But dœ not dull thy palme, with entertainment
Of each vnhatch’t, vnfledg’d Comrade. Beware
Of entrance to a quarrell: but being in
Bear’t that th’oppoſed may beware of thee.
Giue euery man thine eare; but few thy voyce:
Take each mans cenſure; but reſerue thy iudgement:
Coſtly thy habit as thy purſe can buy;
But not expreſt in fancie; rich,not gawdie:
For the Apparell oft proclaimes the man.
And they in France of the beſt ranck and ſtation,
Are of a moſt ſeleƈt and generous cheff in that.
Neither a borrower, nor a lender be;
For lone oft loſes both it ſelfe and friend:
And borrowing duls the edge of Husbandry.
This aboue all; to thine owne ſelfe be true:
And it muſt follow, as the Night the Day,
Thou canſt not then be falſe to any man.
Farewell: my Bleſſing ſeaſon this in thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt humbly dœ I take my leaue, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: The time inuites you, gœ, your ſeruants tend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell Ophelia, and remember well
What I haue ſaid to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Tis in my memory lockt,
And you your ſelfe ſhall keepe the key of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: What iſt Ophelia he hath ſaid to you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: So pleaſe you,ſomthing touching the L. Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, well bethought:
Tis told me he hath very oft of late
Giuen priuate time to you; and you your ſelfe
Haue of your audience beene moſt free and bounteous.
If it be ſo, as ſo tis put on me;
And that in way of caution: I muſt tell you,
You dœ not vnderſtand your ſelfe ſo cleerely,
As it behoues my Daughter, and your Honour.
What is betweene you, giue me vp the truth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath my Lord of late, made many tenders
Of his affeƈtion to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Affeƈtion, puh. You ſpeake like a greene Girle,
Vnſifted in ſuch perillous Circumſtance.
Dœ you beleeue his tenders, as you call them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not know, my Lord, what I ſhould thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Ile teach you; thinke your ſelfe a Baby,
That you haue tane his tenders for true pay,
Which are not ſtarling. Tender your ſelfe more dearly;
Or not to crack the winde of the poore Phraſe,
Roaming it thus, you’l tender me a foole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, he hath importun’d me with loue,
In honourable faſhion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: I,faſhion you may call it, go too, go too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: And hath giuen countenance to his ſpeech,
My Lord, with all the vowes of Heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: I, Springes to catch Woodcocks. I dœ know
When the Bloud burnes,how Prodigall the Soule
Giues the tongue vowes: theſe blazes, Daughter,
Giuing more light then heate; extinƈt in both,
Euen in their promiſe, as it is a making;
You muſt not take for fire. For this time Daughter,
Be ſomewhat ſcanter of your Maiden preſence;
Set your entreatments at a higher rate,
Then a command to parley. For Lord Hamlet,
Beleeue ſo much in him, that he is young,
And with a larger tether may he walke,
Then may be giuen you. In few, Ophelia,
Dœ not beleeue his vowes; for they are Broakers,
Not of the eye, which their Inueſtments ſhow:
But meere implorators of vnholy Sutes,
Breathing like ſanƈtified and pious bonds,
The better to beguile. This is for all:
I would not, in plaine tearmes, from this time forth,
Haue you ſo ſlander any moment leiſure,
As to giue words or talke with the Lord Hamlet:
Looke too’t, I charge you; come your wayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall obey my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The Ayre bites ſhrewdly: is it very cold?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: It is a nipping and an eager ayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What hower now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke it lacks of twelue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: No, it is ſtrooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed I heard it not: then it drawes neere the ſeaſon,
Wherein the Spirit held his wont to walke.
What dœs this meane my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The King doth wake to night, and takes his rouſe,
Keepes waſſels and the ſwaggering vpſpring reeles,
And as he dreines his draughts of Reniſh downe,
The kettle Drum and Trumpet thus bray out
The triumph of his Pledge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Horat.
SPEECH.LINE: Is it a cuſtome?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry iſt;
And to my mind, though I am natiue heere,
And to the manner borne: It is a Cuſtome
More honour’d in the breach, then the obſeruance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke my Lord, it comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Angels and Miniſters of Grace defend vs:
Be thou a Spirit of health, or Goblin damn’d,
Bring with thee ayres from Heauen, or blaſts from Hell,
Be thy euents wicked or charitable,
Thou com’ſt in ſuch a queſtionable ſhape
That I will ſpeake to thee. Ile call thee Hamlet,
King, Father, Royall Dane: Oh, oh, anſwer me,
Let me not burſt in Ignorance; but tell
Why thy Canoniz’d bones Hearſed in death,
Haue burſt their cerments, why the Sepulcher
Wherein we ſaw thee quietly enurn’d,
Hath op’d his ponderous and Marble iawes,
To caſt thee vp againe? What may this meane?
That thou dead Coarſe againe in compleat ſteele,
Reuiſits thus the glimpſes of the Moone,
Making Night hidious? And we fooles of Nature,
So horridly to ſhake our diſpoſition,
With thoughts beyond thee; reaches of our Soules,
Say, why is this? wherefore? what ſhould we dœ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: It beckons you to gœ away with it,
As if it ſome impartment did deſire
To you alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke with what courteous aƈtion
It wafts you to a more remoued ground:
But dœ not gœ with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: No, by no meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It will not ſpeake: then will I follow it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Dœ not my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what ſhould be the feare?
I dœ not ſet my life at a pins fee;
And for my Soule, what can it dœ to that?
Being a thing immortall as it ſelfe:
It waues me forth againe; Ile follow it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: What if it tempt you toward the Floud my Lord?
Or to the dreadfull Sonnet of the Cliffe,
That beetles o’re his baſe into the Sea,
And there aſſumes ſome other horrible forme,
Which might depriue your Soueraignty of Reaſon,
And draw you into madneſſe thinke of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It wafts me ſtill: gœ on, Ile follow thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall not gœ my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Hold off your hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Be rul’d, you ſhall not gœ.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: My fate cries out,
And makes each petty Artire in this body,
As hardy as the Nemian Lions nerue:
Still am I cal’d? Vnhand me Gentlemen:
By Heau’n, Ile make a Ghoſt of him that lets me:
I ſay away, gœ on, Ile follow thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: He waxes deſperate with imagination.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s follow;’tis not fit thus to obey him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue after, to what iſſue will this come?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Something is rotten in the State of Denmarke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen will direƈt it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, let’s follow him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Where wilt thou lead me? ſpeak; Ile go no further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: My hower is almoſt come,
When I to ſulphurous and tormenting Flames
Muſt render vp my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas poore Ghoſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: Pitty me not, but lend thy ſerious hearing
To what I ſhall vnfold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake, I am bound to heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: So art thou to reuenge, when thou ſhalt heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: I am thy Fathers Spirit,
Doom’d for a certaine terme to walke the night;
And for the day confin’d to faſt in Fiers,
Till the foule crimes done in my dayes of Nature
Are burnt and purg’d away? But that I am forbid
To tell the ſecrets of my Priſon-Houſe;
I could a Tale vnfold, whoſe lighteſt word
Would harrow vp thy ſoule, freeze thy young blood,
Make thy two eyes like Starres, ſtart from their Spheres,
Thy knotty and combined lockes to part,
And each particular haire to ſtand an end,
Like Quilles vpon the fretfull Porpentine:
But this eternall blaſon muſt not be
To eares of fleſh and bloud; liſt Hamlet, oh liſt,
If thou didſt euer thy deare Father loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Heauen!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: Reuenge his foule and moſt vnnaturall Murther.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Murther?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Murther moſt foule, as in the beſt it is;
But this moſt foule, ſtrange, and vnnaturall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Haſt, haſt me to know it,
That with wings as ſwift
As meditation, or the thoughts of Loue,
May ſweepe to my Reuenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I finde thee apt,
And duller ſhould’ſt thou be then the fat weede
That rots it ſelfe in eaſe, on Lethe Wharfe,
Would’ſt thou not ſtirre in this. Now Hamlet heare:
It’s giuen out, that ſleeping in mine Orchard,
A Serpent ſtung me: ſo the whole eare of Denmarke,
Is by a forged proceſſe of my death
Rankly abus’d: But know thou Noble youth,
The Serpent that did ſting thy Fathers life,
Now weares his Crowne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Propheticke ſoule: mine Vncle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: I that inceſtuous, that adulterate Beaſt
With witchcraft of his wits, hath Traitorous guifts.
Oh wicked Wit, and Gifts, that haue the power
So to ſeduce? Won to this ſhamefull Luſt
The will of my moſt ſeeming vertuous Queene:
Oh Hamlet, what a falling off was there,
From me, whoſe loue was of that dignity,
That it went hand in hand, euen with the Vow
I made to her in Marriage; and to decline
Vpon a wretch, whoſe Naturall gifts were poore
To thoſe of mine. But Vertue, as it neuer wil be moued,
Though Lewdneſſe court it in a ſhape of Heauen:
So Luſt, though to a radiant Angell link’d,
Will ſate it ſelfe in a Celeſtiallbed, & prey on Garbage.
But ſoft, me thinkes I ſent the Mornings Ayre;
Briefe let me be: Sleeping within mine Orchard,
My cuſtome alwayes in the afternoone;
Vpon my ſecure hower thy Vncle ſtole
With iuyce of curſed Hebenon in a Violl,
And in the Porches of mine eares did poure
The leaperous Diſtilment; whoſe effeƈt
Holds ſuch an enmity with bloud of Man,
That ſwift as Quick-ſiluer, it courſes through
The naturall Gates and Allies of the body;
And with a ſodaine vigour it doth poſſet
And curd, like Aygre droppings into Milke,
The thin and wholſome blood: ſo did it mine;
And a moſt inſtant Tetter bak’d about,
Moſt Lazar-like, with vile and loathſome cruſt,
All my ſmooth Body.
Thus was I, ſleeping, by a Brothers hand,
Of Life, of Crowne, and Queene at once diſpatcht;
Cut off euen in the Bloſſomes of my Sinne,
Vnhouzzled, diſappointed, vnnaneld,
No reckoning made, but ſent to my account
With all my imperfeƈtions on my head;
Oh horrible Oh horrible, moſt horrible:
If thou haſt nature in thee beare it not;
Let not the Royall Bed of Denmarke be
A Couch for Luxury and damned Inceſt.
But howſœuer thou purſueſt this Aƈt,
Taint not thy mind; nor let thy Soule contriue
Againſt thy Mother ought; leaue her to heauen,
And to thoſe Thornes that in her boſome lodge,
To pricke and ſting her. Fare thee well at once;
The Glow-worme ſhowes the Matine to be neere,
And gins to pale his vneffeƈtuall Fire:
Adue, adue, Hamlet: remember me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh all you hoſt of Heauen! Oh Earth; what els?
And ſhall I couple Hell? Oh fie: hold my heart;
And you my ſinnewes, grow not inſtant Old;
But beare me ſtiffely vp: Remember thee?
I, thou poore Ghoſt, while memory holds a ſeate
In this diſtraƈted Globe: Remember thee?
Yea, from the Table of my Memory,
Ile wipe away all triuiall fond Records,
All ſawes of Bookes, all formes, all preſures paſt,
That youth and obſeruation coppied there;
And thy Commandment all alone ſhall liue
Within the Booke and Volume of my Braine,
Vnmixt with baſer matter; yes yes, by Heauen:
Oh moſt pernicious woman!
Oh Villaine, Villaine, ſmiling damned Villaine!
My Tables, my Tables; meet it is I ſet it downe,
That one may ſmile, and ſmile and be a Villaine;
At leaſt I’m ſure it may be ſo in Denmarke;
So Vnckle there you are: now to my word;
It is; Adue, Adue, Remember me: I haue ſworn’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor. & Mar. within.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Lord Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen ſecure him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: So be it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Illo, ho, ho, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Hillo, ho, ho, boy; come bird, come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: How iſ’t my Noble Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: What newes, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh wonderfull!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord tell it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No you’l reueale it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I, my Lord, by Heauen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you then, would heart of man once think it?
But you’l be ſecret?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: I, by Heau’n, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s nere a villaine dwelling in all Denmarke
But hee’s an arrant knaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: There needs no Ghoſt my Lord, come from the
Graue, to tell vs this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why right, you are i’th’right;
And ſo, without more circumſtance at all,
I hold it fit that we ſhake hands, and part:
You, as your buſines and deſires ſhall point you:
For euery man ha’s buſineſſe and deſire,
Such as it is: and for mine owne poore part,
Looke you, Ile gœ pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Theſe are but wild and hurling words, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I’m ſorry they offend you heartily:
Yes faith, heartily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s no offence my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, by Saint Patricke, but there is my Lord,
And much offence too, touching this Viſion heere:
It is an honeſt Ghoſt, that let me tell you:
For your deſire to know what is betweene vs,
O’remaſter’t as you may. And now good friends,
As you are Friends, Schollers and Soldiers,
Giue me one poore requeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: What is’t my Lord? we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer make known what you haue ſeen to night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, we will not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but ſwear’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Infaith my Lord, not I.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mar.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I my Lord: in faith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Marcell.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue ſworne my Lord already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed, vpon my ſword, Indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho
SPEECH.LINE: Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah ha boy, ſayeſt thou ſo. Art thou there true-
penny? Come one you here this fellow in the ſelleredge
Conſent to ſweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Propoſe the Oath my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer to ſpeake of this that you haue ſeene.
Sweare by my ſword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Hic & vbique? Then wee’l ſhift for grownd,
Come hither Gentlemen,
And lay your hands againe vpon my ſword,
Neuer to ſpeake of this that you haue heard:
Sweare by my Sword.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gho.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Well ſaid old Mole, can’ſt worke i’th’ ground ſo faſt?
A worthy Pioner, once more remoue good friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh day and night: but this is wondrous ſtrange.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: And therefore as a ſtranger giue it welcome.
There are more things in Heauen and Earth, Horatio,
Then are dream’t of in our Philoſophy. But come,
Here as before, neuer ſo helpe you mercy,
How ſtrange or odde ſo ere I beare my ſelfe;
(As I perchance heereafter ſhall thinke meet
To put an Anticke diſpoſition on:)
That you at ſuch time ſeeing me, neuer ſhall
With Armes encombred thus, or thus, head ſhake;
Or by pronouncing of ſome doubtfull Phraſe;
As well, we know, or we could and if we would,
Or if we liſt to ſpeake; or there be and if there might,
Or ſuch ambiguous giuing out to note,
That you know ought of me; this not to dœ:
So grace and mercy at your moſt neede helpe you:
Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Reſt, reſt perturbed Spirit: ſo Gentlemen,
With all my loue I dœ commend me to you;
And what ſo poore a man as Hamlet is,
May dœ t’expreſſe his loue and friending to you,
God willing ſhall not lacke: let vs gœ in together,
And ſtill your fingers on your lippes I pray,
The time is out of ioynt: Oh curſed ſpight,
That euer I was borne to ſet it right.
Nay, come let’s gœ together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue him his money, and theſe notes Reynoldo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: I will my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhall dœ maruels wiſely: good Reynoldo,
Before you viſite him you make inquiry
Of his behauiour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I did intend it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, well ſaid;
Very well ſaid. Looke you Sir,
Enquire me firſt what Danskers are in Paris;
And how, and who; what meanes; and where they keepe:
What company, at what expence: and finding
By this encompaſſement and drift of queſtion,
That they dœ know my ſonne: Come you more neerer
Then your particular demands will touch it,
Take you as ’twere ſome diſtant knowledge of him,
And thus I know his father and his friends,
And in part him. Dœ you marke this Reynoldo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: I, very well my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: And in part him,but you may ſay not well;
But if’t be hee I meane, hees very wilde;
Addiƈted ſo and ſo; and there put on him
What forgeries you pleaſe; marry, none ſo ranke,
As may diſhonour him; take heed of that:
But Sir, ſuch wanton, wild, and vſuall ſlips,
As are Companions noted and moſt knowne
To youth and liberty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: As gaming my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or drinking, fencing, ſwearing,
Quarelling, drabbing. You may gœ ſo farre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord that would diſhonour him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith no, as you may ſeaſon it in the charge;
You muſt not put another ſcandall on him,
That hee is open to Incontinencie;
That’s not my meaning: but breath his faults ſo quaintly,
That they may ſeeme the taints of liberty;
The flaſh and out-breake of a fiery minde,
A ſauagenes in vnreclaim’d bloud of generall aſſault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: But my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Wherefore ſhould you dœ this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord, I would know that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry Sir, heere’s my drift,
And I belieue it is a fetch of warrant:
You laying theſe ſlight ſulleyes on my Sonne,
As ’twere a thing a little ſoil’d i’th’ working:
Marke you your party in conuerſe; him you would ſound,
Hauing euer ſeene. In the prenominate crimes,
The youth you breath of guilty, be aſſur’d
He cloſes with you in this conſequence:
Good ſir, or ſo, or friend, or Gentleman.
According to the Phraſe and the Addition,
Of man and Country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: Very good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: And then Sir dœs he this?
He dœs: what was I about to ſay?
I was about to ſay ſomthing: where did I leaue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: At cloſes in the conſequence:
At friend, or ſo, and Gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: At cloſes in the conſequence, I marry,
He cloſes with you thus. I know the Gentleman,
I ſaw him yeſterday, or tother day;
Or then or then, with ſuch and ſuch; and as you ſay,
There was he gaming, there o’retooke in’s Rouſe,
There falling out at Tennis; or perchance,
I ſaw him enter ſuch a houſe of ſaile;
Videlicet, a Brothell, or ſo forth. See you now;
Your bait of falſhood, takes this Cape of truth;
And thus dœ we of wiſedome and of reach
With windleſſes, and with aſſaies of Bias,
By indireƈtions finde direƈtions out:
So by my former Leƈture and aduice
Shall you my Sonne; you haue me, haue you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord I haue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: God buy you; fare you well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Obſerue his inclination in your ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: And let him plye his Muſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynol.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Farewell:
How now Ophelia, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas my Lord, I haue beene ſo affrighted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: With what, in the name of Heauen?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, as I was ſowing in my Chamber,
Lord Hamlet with his doublet all vnbrac’d,
No hat vpon his head, his ſtockings foul’d,
Vngartred, and downe giued to his Anckle,
Pale as his ſhirt, his knees knocking each other,
And with a looke ſo pitious in purport,
As if he had been looſed out of hell,
To ſpeake of horrors: he comes before me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Mad for thy Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I dœ not know: but truly I do feare it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſaid he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: He tooke me by the wriſt, and held me hard;
Then gœs he to the length of all his arme;
And with his other hand thus o’re his brow,
He fals to ſuch peruſall of my face,
As he would draw it. Long ſtaid he ſo,
At laſt, a little ſhaking of mine Arme:
And thrice his head thus wauing vp and downe;
He rais’d a ſigh, ſo pittious and profound,
That it did ſeeme to ſhatter all his bulke,
And end his being. That done, he lets me gœ,
And with his head ouer his ſhoulders turn’d,
He ſeem’d to finde his way without his eyes,
For out a dores he went without their helpe;
And to the laſt, bended their light on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Gœ with me, I will gœ ſeeke the King,
This is the very extaſie of Loue,
Whoſe violent property foredœs it ſelfe,
And leads the will to deſperate Vndertakings,
As oft as any paſſion vnder Heauen,
That dœs affliƈt our Natures. I am ſorrie,
What haue you giuen him any hard words of late?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord: but as you did command,
I did repell his Letters, and deny’de
His acceſſe to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: That hath made him mad.
I am ſorrie that with better ſpeed and iudgement
I had not quoted him. I feare he did but trifle,
And meant to wracke thee: but beſhrew my iealouſie:
It ſeemes it is as proper to our Age,
To caſt beyond our ſelues in our Opinions,
As it is common for the yonger ſort
To lacke diſcretion. Come, go we to the King,
This muſt be knowne, being kept cloſe might moue
More greefe to hide, then hate to vtter loue.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter King, Queene, Roſincrane, and Guildenſterne Cum alijs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Welcome deere Roſincrance and Guildenſterne.
Moreouer, that we much did long to ſee you,
The neede we haue to vſe you, did prouoke
Our haſtie ſending. Something haue you heard
Of Hamlets transformation: ſo I call it,
Since not th’exterior, nor the inward man
Reſembles that it was. What it ſhould bee
More then his Fathers death, that thus hath put him
So much from th’vnderſtanding of himſelfe,
I cannot deeme of. I intreat you both,
That being of ſo young dayes brought vp with him:
And ſince ſo Neighbour’d to his youth, and humour,
That you vouchſafe your reſt heere in our Court
Some little time: ſo by your Companies
To draw him on to pleaſures, and to gather
So much as from Occaſions you may gleane,
That open’d lies within our remedie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Gentlemen, he hath much talk’d of you,
And ſure I am, two men there are not liuing,
To whom he more adheres. If it will pleaſe you
To ſhew vs ſo much Gentrie, and good will,
As to expend your time with vs a-while,
For the ſupply and profit of our Hope,
Your Viſitation ſhall receiue ſuch thankes
As fits a Kings remembrance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Both your Maieſties
Might by the Soueraigne power you haue of vs,
Put your dread pleaſures, more into Command
Then to Entreatie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: We both obey,
And here giue vp our ſelues, in the full bent,
To lay our Seruices freely at your feete,
To be commanded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thankes Roſincrance, and gentle Guildenſterne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Thankes Guildenſterne and gentle Roſincrance.
And I beſeech you inſtantly to viſit
My too much changed Sonne.
Go ſome of ye,
And bring the Gentlemen where Hamlet is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauens make our preſence and our praƈtiſes
Pleaſant and helpfull to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queene.
SPEECH.LINE: Amen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Th’Ambaſſadors from Norwey, my good Lord,
Are ioyfully return’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſtill haſt bin the father of good Newes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue I, my Lord? Aſſure you, my good Liege,
I hold my dutie, as I hold my Soule,
Both to my God, one to my gracious King:
And I do thinke, or elſe this braine of mine
Hunts not the traile of Policie, ſo ſure
As I haue vs’d to do: that I haue found
The very cauſe of Hamlets Lunacie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſpeake of that, that I do long to heare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue firſt admittance to th’Ambaſſadors,
My Newes ſhall be the Newes to that great Feaſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy ſelfe do grace to them, and bring them in.
He tels me my ſweet Queene, that he hath found
The head and ſourſe of all your Sonnes diſtemper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I doubt it is no other, but the maine,
His Fathers death, and our o’re-haſty Marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, we ſhall ſift him. Welcome good Frends:
Say Voltumand, what from our Brother Norwey?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Volt.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt faire returne of Greetings, and Deſires.
Vpon our firſt, he ſent out to ſuppreſſe
His Nephewes Leuies, which to him appear’d
To be a preparation ’gainſt the Poleak:
But better look’d into, he truly found
It was againſt your Highneſſe, whereat greeued,
That ſo his Sickneſſe, Age, and Impotence
Was falſely borne in hand, ſends out Arreſts
On Fortinbras, which he (in breefe) obeyes,
Receiues rebuke from Norwey: and in fine,
Makes Vow before his Vnkle, neuer more
To giue th’aſſay of Armes againſt your Maieſtie.
Whereon old Norwey, ouercome with ioy,
Giues him three thouſand Crownes in Annuall Fee,
And his Commiſſion to imploy thoſe Soldiers
So leuied as before, againſt the Poleak:
With an intreaty heerein further ſhewne,
That it might pleaſe you to giue quiet paſſe
Through your Dominions, for his Enterprize,
On ſuch regards of ſafety and allowance,
As therein are ſet downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: It likes vs well:
And at our more conſider’d time wee’l read,
Anſwer, and thinke vpon this Buſineſſe.
Meane time we thanke you, for your well-tooke Labour.
Go to your reſt, at night wee’l Feaſt together.
Moſt welcome home.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: This buſineſſe is very well ended.
My Liege, and Madam, to expoſtulate
What Maieſtie ſhould be, what Dutie is,
Why day is day; night, night; and time is time,
Were nothing but to waſte Night, Day and Time.
Therefore, ſince Breuitie is the Soule of Wit,
And tediouſneſſe, the limbes and outward flouriſhes,
I will be breefe. Your Noble Sonne is mad:
Mad call I it; for to define true Madneſſe,
What is’t, but to be nothing elſe but mad.
But let that go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: More matter, with leſſe Art.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I ſweare I vſe no Art at all:
That he is mad, ’tis true: ’Tis true ’tis pittie,
And pittie it is true: A fooliſh figure,
But farewell it: for I will vſe no Art.
Mad let vs grant him then: and now remaines
That we finde out the cauſe of this effeƈt,
Or rather ſay, the cauſe of this defeƈt;
For this effeƈt defeƈtiue, comes by cauſe,
Thus it remaines, and the remainder thus. Perpend,
I haue a daughter: haue, whil’ſt ſhe is mine,
Who in her Dutie and Obedience,marke,
Hath giuen me this: now gather, and ſurmiſe.

LINE.ITALIC: To the Celeſtiall, and my Soules Idoll, the moſt beautifed

SPEECH.LINE: phelia.
That’s an ill Phraſe, a vilde Phraſe, beautified is a vilde
Phraſe: but you ſhall heare theſe in her excellent white
boſome, theſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Came this from Hamlet to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam ſtay awhile, I will be faithfull.

LINE.ITALIC: Doubt thou,the Starres are fire,
Doubt, that the Sunne doth moue:
Doubt Truth to be a Lier,
But neuer Doubt, I loue.
O deere Ophelia, I am ill at theſe Numbers: I haue not Art to
reckon my grones; but that I loue thee beſt, oh moſt Beſt be-
leeue it. Adieu.
Thine euermore moſt deere Lady,whilſt this

SPEECH.LINE: Machine is to him, Hamlet.
This in Obedience hath my daughter ſhew’d me:
And more aboue hath his ſoliciting,
As they fell out by Time, by Meanes,and Place,
All giuen to mine eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: But how hath ſhe receiu’d his Loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: What do you thinke of me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: As of a man, faithfull and Honourable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: I wold faine proue ſo. But what might you think?
When I had ſeene this hot loue on the wing,
As I perceiued it, I muſt tell you that
Before my Daughter told me what might you
Or my deere Maieſtie your Queene heere, think,
If I had playd the Deske or Table-booke,
Or giuen my heart a winking, mute and dumbe,
Or look’d vpon this Loue, with idle ſight,
What might you thinke? No, I went round to worke,
And (my yong Miſtris) thus I did beſpeake
Lord Hamlet is a Prince out of thy Starre,
This muſt not be: and then, I Precepts gaue her,
That ſhe ſhould locke her ſelfe from his Reſort,
Admit no Meſſengers, receiue no Tokens:
Which done, ſhe tooke the Fruites of my Aduice,
And he repulſed. A ſhort Tale to make,
Fell into a Sadneſſe, then into a Faſt,
Thence to a Watch, thence into a Weakneſſe,
Thence to a Lightneſſe, and by this declenſion
Into the Madneſſe whereon now he raues,
And all we waile for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you thinke ’tis this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: It may be very likely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Hath there bene ſuch a time, I’de fain know that,
That I haue poſſitiuely ſaid, ’tis ſo,
When it prou’d otherwiſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Not that I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Take this from this; if this be otherwiſe,
If Circumſtances leade me, I will finde
Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeede
Within the Center.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: How may we try it further?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: You know ſometimes
He walkes foure houres together, heere
In the Lobby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: So he ha’s indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: At ſuch a time Ile looſe my Daughter to him,
Be you and I behinde an Arras then,
Marke the encounter: If he loue her not,
And be not from his reaſon falne thereon;
Let me be no Aſſiſtant for a State,
And keepe a Farme and Carters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: We will try it.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hamlet reading on a Booke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: But looke where ſadly the poore wretch
Comes reading.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Away I do beſeech you, both away,
Ile boord him preſently.
Oh giue me leaue. How dœs my good Lord Hamlet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, God-a-mercy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you know me, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellent, excellent well: y’are a Fiſhmonger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Not I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then I would you were ſo honeſt a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Honeſt, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, to be honeſt as this world gœs, is to bee
one man pick’d out of two thouſand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s very true, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: For if the Sun breed Magots in a dead dogge,
being a good kiſſing Carrion—
Haue you a daughter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Let her not walke i’th Sunne: Conception is a
bleſsing, but not as your daughter may conceiue. Friend
looke too’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſay you by that? Still harping on my daugh-
ter: yet he knew me not at firſt; he ſaid I was a Fiſhmon-:
ger he is farre gone, farre gone: and truly in my youth,
I ſuffred much extreamity for loue: very neere this. Ile
ſpeake to him againe. What do you read my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Words, words, words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the matter, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Betweene who?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane the matter you meane, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Slanders Sir: for the Satyricall ſlaue ſaies here,
that old men haue gray Beards; that their faces are wrin-;
kled their eyes purging thicke Amber, or Plum-Tree
Gumme: and that they haue a plentifull locke of Wit,
together with weake Hammes. All which Sir, though I
moſt powerfully, and potently beleeue; yet I holde it
not Honeſtie to haue it thus ſet downe: For you your
ſelfe Sir, ſhould be old as I am, if like a Crab you could
go backward.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Though this be madneſſe,
Yet there is Method in’t: will you walke
Out of the ayre my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Into my Graue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed that is out o’th’Ayre:
How pregnant (ſometimes)his Replies are?
A happineſſe,
That often Madneſſe hits on,
Which Reaſon and Sanitie could not
So proſperouſly be deliuer’d of.
I will leaue him,
And ſodainely contriue the meanes of meeting
Betweene him, and my daughter.
My Honourable Lord, I will moſt humbly
Take my leaue of you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: You cannot Sir take from me any thing, that I
will more willingly part withall, except my life, my
life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Fare you well my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Theſe tedious old fooles.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: You gœ to ſeeke my Lord Hamlet; there
hee is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: God ſaue you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine honour’d Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: My moſt deare Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: My excellent good friends? How do’ſt thou
Guildenſterne? Oh,Roſincrane; good Lads: How dœ ye
both?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: As the indifferent Children of the earth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Happy, in that we are not ouer-happy: on For-
tunes Cap, we are not the very Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor the Soales of her Shoo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Neither my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then you liue about her waſte, or in the mid-
dle of her fauour?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith, her priuates, we.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: In the ſecret parts of Fortune? Oh, moſt true:
she is a Strumpet. What’s the newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: None my Lord; but that the World’s growne
honeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then is Doomeſday neere: But your newes is
not true. Let me queſtion more in particular: what haue
you my good friends, deſerued at the hands of Fortune,
that ſhe ſends you to Priſon hither?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: Priſon, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Denmark’s a Priſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then is the World one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A goodly one, in which there are many Con-
fines, Wards, and Dungeons; Denmarke being one o’th’
worſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: We thinke not ſo my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then ’tis none to you; for there is nothing
either good or bad, but thinking makes it ſo: to me it is
a priſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then your Ambition makes it one: ’tis
too narrow for your minde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: O God, I could be bounded in a nutſhell, and
count my ſelfe a King of infinite ſpace; were it not that
I haue bad dreames.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: Which dreames indeed are Ambition: for the
very ſubſtance of the Ambitious, is meerely the ſhadow
of a Dreame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A dreame it ſelfe is but a ſhadow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Truely, and I hold Ambition of ſo ayry and
light a quality, that it is but a ſhadowes ſhadow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then are our Beggers bodies; and our Mo-
narchs and out-ſtretcht Herœs the Beggers Shadowes:
shall wee to th’Court: for, by my fey I cannot rea-
ſon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’l wait vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No ſuch matter. I will not ſort you with the
reſt of my ſeruants: for to ſpeake to you like an honeſt
man: I am moſt dreadfully attended; but in the beaten
way of friendſhip, What make you at Elſonower?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: To viſit you my Lord, no other occaſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Begger that I am, I am euen poore in thankes;
but I thanke you: and ſure deare friends my thanks
are too deare a halfepeny; were you not ſent for? Is it
your owne inclining? Is it a free viſitation? Come,
deale iuſtly with me: come, come; nay ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhould we ſay my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why any thing. But to the purpoſe; you were
ſent for; and there is a kinde confeſſion in your lookes;
which your modeſties haue not craft enough to co-
lor, I know the good King & Queene haue ſent for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: To what end my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That you muſt teach me: but let mee coniure
you by the rights of our fellowſhip, by the conſonancy of
our youth, by the Obligation of our euer-preſerued loue,
and by what more deare, a better propoſer could charge
you withall; be euen and direƈt with me, whether you
were ſent for or no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay then I haue an eye of you: if you loue me
hold not off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, we were ſent for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I will tell you why; ſo ſhall my anticipation
preuent your diſcouery of your ſecricie to the King and
Queene:moult no feather, I haue of late, but wherefore
I know not, loſt all my mirth, forgone all cuſtome of ex-;
erciſe and indeed, it gœs ſo heauenly with my diſpoſiti-
on;that this goodly frame the Earth, ſeemes to me a ſter-
rill Promontory; this moſt excellent Canopy the Ayre,
look you, this braue ore-hanging, this Maieſticall Roofe,
fretted with golden fire: why, it appeares no other thing
to mee, then a foule and peſtilent congregation of va-
pours. What a piece of worke is a man! how Noble in
Reaſon? how infinite in faculty? in forme and mouing
how expreſſe and admirable? in Aƈtion, how like an An-
gel? in apprehenſion, how like a God? the beauty of the
world, the Parragon of Animals; and yet to me, what is
this Quinteſſence of Duſt? Man delights not me; no,
nor Woman neither; though by your ſmiling you ſeeme
to ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, there was no ſuch ſtuffe in my
thoughts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why did you laugh, when I ſaid, Man delights
not me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: To thinke, my Lord, if you delight not in Man,
what Lenton entertainment the Players ſhall receiue
from you: wee coated them on the way, and hither are
they comming to offer you Seruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: He that playes the King ſhall be welcome; his
Maieſty ſhall haue Tribute of mee: the aduenturous
Knight ſhal vſe his Foyle and Target: the Louer ſhall
not ſigh gratis, the humorous man ſhall end his part in
peace: the Clowne ſhall make thoſe laugh whoſe lungs
are tickled a’th’ſere: and the Lady ſhall ſay her minde
freely;or the blanke Verſe ſhall halt for’t: what Players
are they?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen thoſe you were wont to take delight in
the Tragedians of the City.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How chances it they trauaile? their reſi-
dence both in reputation and profit was better both
wayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke their Inhibition comes by the meanes
of the late Innouation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Dœ they hold the ſame eſtimation they did
when I was in the City? Are they ſo follow’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: No indeed, they are not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How comes it? dœ they grow ruſty?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, their indeauour keepes in the wonted
pace; But there is Sir an ayrie of Children, little
Yaſes, that crye out on the top of queſtion; and
are moſt tyrannically clap’t for’t: theſe are now the
faſhion, and ſo be-ratled the common Stages (ſo they
call them) that many wearing Rapiers, are affraide of
Gooſe-quils, and dare ſcarſe come thither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What are they Children? Who maintains ’em?
How are they eſcorted? Will they purſue the Quality no
longer then they can ſing? Will they not ſay afterwards
if they ſhould grow themſelues to common Players (as
it is moſt like if their meanes are not better) their Wri-
ters do them wrong, to make them exclaim againſt their
owne Succeſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith there ha’s bene much to do on both ſides:
and the Nation holds it no ſinne, to tarre them to Con-.
trouerſie. There was for a while, no mony bid for argu-
ment, vnleſſe the Pœt and the Player went to Cuffes in
the Queſtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Is’t poſſible?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh there ha’s beene much throwing about of
Braines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Do the Boyes carry it away?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: I that they do my Lord.Hercules & his load too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſtrange: for mine Vnckle is King of
Denmarke, and thoſe that would make mowes at him
while my Father liued; giue twenty, forty, an hundred
Ducates a peece, for his piƈture in Little. There is ſome-
thing in this more then Naturall, if Philoſophie could
finde it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: There are the Players.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Gentlemen, you are welcom to Elſonower: your
hands, come: The appurtenance of Welcome, is Faſhion
and Ceremony. Let me comply with you in the Garbe,
leſt my extent to the Players (which I tell you muſt ſhew
fairely outward) ſhould more appeare like entertainment
then yours. You are welcome: but my Vnckle Father,
and Aunt Mother are deceiu’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: In what my deere Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I am but mad North, North-Weſt: when the
Winde is Southerly, I know a Hawke from a Handſaw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Well be with you Gentlemen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Hearke you Guildenſterne,and you too: at each
eare a hearer: that great Baby you ſee there, is not yet
out of his ſwathing clouts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Happily he’s the ſecond time come to them: for
they ſay, an old man is twice a childe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I will Propheſie. Hee comes to tell me of the
Players. Mark it, you ſay right Sir: for a Monday mor-
ning ’twas ſo indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I haue Newes to tell you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I haue Newes to tell you.
When Roſſius an Aƈtor in Rome—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: The Aƈtors are come hither my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Buzze, buzze.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon mine Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then can each Aƈtor on his Aſſe—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: The beſt Aƈtors in the world, either for Trage-
die, Comedie, Hiſtorie, Paſtorall: Paſtoricall-Comicall-
Hiſtoricall-Paſtorall: Tragicall-Hiſtoricall: Tragicall-
Comicall-Hiſtoricall-Paſtorall: Scene indiuidible: or Po-
em vnlimited. Seneca cannot be too heauy, nor Plautus
too light, for the law of Writ, and the Liberty. Theſe are
the onely men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: O Iephta Iudge of Iſrael, what a Treaſure had’ſt
thou?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: What a Treaſure had he, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why one faire Daughter, and no more,
The which he loued paſſing well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Still on my Daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Am I not i’th’right old Iephta?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: If you call me Iephta my Lord, I haue a daugh-
ter that I loue paſſing well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay that followes not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: What followes then, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ha.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, As by lot, God wot: and then you know, It
came to paſſe, as moſt like it was: The firſt rowe of the
Pons Chanſon will ſhew you more. For looke where my
Abridgements come.
Y’are welcome Maſters, welcome all. I am glad to ſee
thee well: Welcome good Friends. Oh my olde Friend?
Thy face is valiant ſince I ſaw thee laſt: Com’ſt thou to
beard me in Denmarke? What, my yong Lady and Mi-
ſtris? Byrlady your Ladiſhip is neerer Heauen then when
I ſaw you laſt, by the altitude of a Choppine. Pray God
your voice like a peece of vncurrant Gold be not crack’d
within the ring. Maſters,you are all welcome:wee’l e’ne
to’t like French Faulconers, flie at any thing we ſee: wee’l
haue a Speech ſtraight. Come giue vs a taſt of your qua-
lity: come, a paſſionate ſpeech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Play.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſpeech, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I heard thee ſpeak me a ſpeech once, but it was
neuer Aƈted: or if it was, not aboue once, for the Play I
remember pleas’d not the Million, ’twas Cauiarie to the
Generall: but it was (as I receiu’d it, and others, whoſe
iudgement in ſuch matters, cried in the top of mine) an
excellent Play; well digeſted in the Scœnes, ſet downe
with as much modeſtie, as cunning. I remember one ſaid,
there was no Sallets in the lines, to make the matter ſa-
uory; nor no matter in the phraſe, that might indite the
Author of affeƈtation, but cal’d it an honeſt method. One
cheefe Speech in it, I cheefely lou’d, ’twas Æneas Tale
to Dido, and thereabout of it eſpecially, where he ſpeaks
of Priams ſlaughter. If it liue in your memory, begin at
this Line, let me ſee,let me ſee: The rugged Pyrrhus like
th’Hyrcanian Beaſt. It is not ſo: it begins with Pyrrhus
The rugged Pyrrhus, he whoſe Sable Armes
Blacke as his purpoſe, did the night reſemble
When he lay couched in the Ominous Horſe,
Hath now this dread and blacke Complexion ſmear’d
With Heraldry more diſmall: Head to foote
Now is he to take Geulles, horridly Trick’d
With blood of Fathers, Mothers, Daughters, Sonnes,
Bak’d and impaſted with the parching ſtreets,
That lend a tyrannous, and damned light
To their vilde Murthers, roaſted in wrath and fire,
And thus o’re-ſized with coagulate gore,
With eyes like Carbuncles, the helliſh Pyrrhus
Olde Grandſire Priam ſeekes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Fore God,my Lord, well ſpoken, with good ac-
cent, and good diſcretion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Player.
SPEECH.LINE: Anon he findes him,
Striking too ſhort at Greekes. His anticke Sword,
Rebellious to his Arme, lyes where it falles
Repugnant to command: vnequall match,
Pyrrhus at Priam driues, in Rage ſtrikes wide:
But with the whiffe and winde of his fell Sword,
Th’vnnerued Father fals. Then ſenſeleſſe Illium,
Seeming to feele his blow, with flaming top
Stoopes to his Bace, and with a hideous craſh
Takes Priſoner Pyrrhus eare. For lœ, his Sword
Which was declining on the Milkie head
Of Reuerend Priam, ſeem’d i’th’Ayre to ſticke:
So as a painted Tyrant Pyrrhus ſtood,
And like a Newtrall to his will and matter, did nothing.
But as we often ſee againſt ſome ſtorme,
A ſilence in the Heauens, the Racke ſtand ſtill,
The bold windes ſpeechleſſe, and the Orbe below
As huſh as death: Anon the dreadfull Thunder
Doth rend the Region. So after Pyrrhus pauſe,
A rowſed Vengeance ſets him new a-worke,
And neuer did the Cyclops hammers fall
On Mars his Armours, forg’d for proofe Eterne,
With leſſe remorſe then Pyrrhus bleeding ſword
Now falles on Priam.
Out, out, thou Strumpet-Fortune, all you Gods,
In generall Synod take away her power:
Breake all the Spokes and Fallies from her wheele,
And boule the round Naue downe the hill of Heauen,
As low as to the Fiends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: This is too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall to’th Barbars, with your beard. Pry-
thee ſay on: He’s for a Iigge, or a tale of Baudry, or hee
sleepes. Say on; come to Hecuba.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Play.
SPEECH.LINE: But who, O who, had ſeen the inobled Queen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The inobled Queene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s good: Inobled Queene is good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: 1.Play.
SPEECH.LINE: Run bare-foot vp and downe,
Threatning the flame
With Biſſon Rheume: A clout about that head,
Where late the Diadem ſtood, and for a Robe
About her lanke and all ore-teamed Loines,
A blanket in th’Alarum of feare caught vp.
Who this had ſeene, with tongue in Venome ſteep’d,
’Gainſt Fortunes State, would Treaſon haue pronounc’d?
But if the Gods themſelues did ſee her then,
When ſhe ſaw Pyrrhus make malicious ſport
In mincing with his Sword her Husbands limbes,
The inſtant Burſt of Clamour that ſhe made
(Vnleſſe things mortall moue them not at all)
Would haue made milche the Burning eyes of Heauen,
And paſſion in the Gods.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke where he ha’s not turn’d his colour, and
ha’s teares in’s eyes. Pray you no more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis well, Ile haue thee ſpeake out the reſt,
soone. Good my Lord, will you ſee the Players wel be-
ſtow’d. Do ye heare, let them be well vs’d: for they are
the Abſtraƈts and breefe Chronicles of the time. After
your death, you were better haue a bad Epitaph, then
their ill report while you liued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I will vſe them according to their de-
sart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Gods bodykins man, better. Vſe euerie man
after his deſart, and who ſhould ſcape whipping: vſe
them after your own Honor and Dignity. The leſſe they
deſerue, the more merit is in your bountie. Take them
in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſirs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow him Friends: wee’l heare a play to mor-
row. Doſt thou heare me old Friend, can you play the
murther of Gonzago?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Play.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Wee’l ha’t to morrow night. You could for a
need ſtudy a ſpeech of ſome doſen or ſixteene lines,which
I would ſet downe, and inſert in’t? Could ye not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Play.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Very well. Follow that Lord, and looke you
mock him not. My good Friends, Ile leaue you til night
you are welcome to Elſonower?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſo, God buy’ye: Now I am alone.
Oh what a Rogue and Peſant ſlaue am I?
Is it not monſtrous that this Player heere,
But in a Fixion, in a dreame of Paſſion,
Could force his ſoule ſo to his whole conceit,
That from her working, all his viſage warm’d;
Teares in his eyes, diſtraƈtion in’s Aſpeƈt,
A broken voyce, and his whole Funƈtion ſuiting
With Formes, to his Conceit? And all for nothing?
For Hecuba?
What’s Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba,
That he ſhould weepe for her? What would he dœ,
Had he the Motiue and the Cue for paſſion
That I haue? He would drowne the Stage with teares,
And cleaue the generall eare with horrid ſpeech:
Make mad the guilty, and apale the free,
Confound the ignorant, and amaze indeed,
The very faculty of Eyes and Eares. Yet I,
A dull and muddy-metled Raſcall, peake
Like Iohn a-dreames, vnpregnant of my cauſe,
And can ſay nothing: No, not for a King,
Vpon whoſe property, and moſt deere life,
A damn’d defeate was made. Am I a Coward?
Who calles me Villaine? breakes my pate a-croſſe?
Pluckes off my Beard, and blowes it in my face?
Tweakes me by’th’Noſe? giues me the Lye i’th’Throate,
As deepe as to the Lungs? Who dœs me this?
Ha? Why I ſhould take it: for it cannot be,
But I am Pigeon-Liuer’d, and lacke Gall
To make Oppreſſion bitter,or ere this,
I ſhould haue fatted all the Region Kites
With this Slaues Offall, bloudy: a Bawdy villaine,
Remorſeleſſe, Treacherous,Letcherous, kindles villaine!
Oh Vengeance!
Who? What an Aſſe am I? I ſure, this is moſt braue,
That I, the Sonne of the Deere murthered,
Prompted to my Reuenge by Heauen, and Hell,
Muſt (like a Whore) vnpacke my heart with words,
And fall a Curſing like a very Drab.
A Scullion? Fye vpon’t: Foh. About my Braine.
I haue heard, that guilty Creatures ſitting at a Play,
Haue by the very cunning of the Scœne,
Bene ſtrooke ſo to the ſoule, that preſently
They haue proclaim’d their Malefaƈtions.
For Murther, though it haue no tongue, will ſpeake
With moſt myraculous Organ. Ile haue theſe Players,
Play ſomething like the murder of my Father,
Before mine Vnkle. Ile obſerue his lookes,
Ile rent him to the quicke: If he but blench
I know my courſe. The Spirit that I haue ſeene
May be the Diuell, and the Diuel hath power
T’aſſume a pleaſing ſhape, yea and perhaps
Out of my Weakneſſe, and my Melancholly,
As he is very potent with ſuch Spirits,
Abuſes me to damne me. Ile haue grounds
More Relatiue then this: The Play’s the thing,
Wherein Ile catch the Conſcience of the King.
