SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter King, Queene, Polonius, Ophelia, Roſincrance, Guildenſtern, and Lords

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: And can you by no drift of circumſtance
Get from him why he puts on this Confuſion:
Grating ſo harſhly all his dayes of quiet
With turbulent and dangerous Lunacy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: He dœs confeſſe he feeles himſelfe diſtraƈted,
But from what cauſe he will by no meanes ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guil.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor do we finde him forward to be ſounded,
But with a crafty Madneſſe keepes aloofe:
When we would bring him on to ſome Confeſſion
Of his true ſtate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Did he receiue you well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Moſt like a Gentleman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: But with much forcing of his diſpoſition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Niggard of queſtion, but of our demands
Moſt free in his reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Did you aſſay him to any paſtime?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, it ſo fell out, that certaine Players
We ore-wrought on the way: of theſe we told him,
And there did ſeeme in him a kinde of ioy
To heare of it: They are about the Court,
And (as I thinke) they haue already order
This night to play before him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis moſt true:
And he beſeech’d me to intreate your Maieſties
To heare, and ſee the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart, and it doth much content me
To heare him ſo inclin’d. Good Gentlemen,
Giue him a further edge, and driue his purpoſe on
To theſe delights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Gertrude leaue vs too,
For we haue cloſely ſent for Hamlet hither,
That he, as ’twere by accident, may there
Affront Ophelia. Her Father, and my ſelfe (lawful eſpials)
Will ſo beſtow our ſelues, that ſeeing vnſeene
We may of their encounter frankely iudge,
And gather by him, as he is behaued,
If’t be th’affliƈtion of his loue,or no.
That thus he ſuffers for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall obey you,
And for your part Ophelia, I do wiſh
That your good Beauties be the happy cauſe
Of Hamlets wildeneſſe: ſo ſhall I hope your Vertues
Will bring him to his wonted way againe,
To both your Honors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I wiſh it may.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Ophelia, walke you heere. Gracious ſo pleaſe ye
We will beſtow our ſelues: Reade on this booke,
That ſhew of ſuch an exerciſe may colour
Your lonelineſ༃e. We are oft too blame in this,
’Tis too much prou’d, that with Deuotions viſage,
And pious Aƈtion, we do ſurge o’re
The diuell himſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ’tis true:
How ſmart a laſh that ſpeech doth giue my Conſcience?
The Harlots Cheeke beautied with plaiſt’ring Art
Is not more vgly to the thing that helpes it,
Then is my deede, to my moſt painted word.
Oh heauie burthen!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: I heare him comming, let’s withdraw my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: To be, or not to be, that is the Queſtion:
Whether ’tis Nobler in the minde to ſuffer
The Slings and Arrowes of outragious Fortune,
Or to take Armes againſt a Sea of troubles,
And by oppoſing end them: to dye, to ſleepe
No more; and by a ſleepe, to ſay we end
The Heart-ake, and the thouſand Naturall ſhockes
That Fleſh is heyre too? ’Tis a conſummation
Deuoutly to be wiſh’d. To dye to ſleepe,
To ſleepe, perchance to Dreame; I, there’s the rub,
For in that ſleepe of death, what dreames may come,
When we haue ſhuffel’d off this mortall coile,
Muſt giue vs pawſe. There’s the reſpeƈt
That makes Calamity of ſo long life:
For who would beare the Whips and Scornes of time,
The Oppreſſors wrong, the poore mans Contumely,
The pangs of diſpriz’d Loue, the Lawes delay,
The inſolence of Office, and the Spurnes
That patient merit of the vnworthy takes,
When he himſelfe might his Quietus make
With a bare Bodkin? Who would theſe Fardles beare
To grunt and ſweat vnder a weary life,
But that the dread of ſomething after death,
The vndiſcouered Countrey, from whoſe Borne
No Traueller returnes, Puzels the will,
And makes vs rather beare thoſe illes we haue,
Then flye to others that we know not of.
Thus Conſcience dœs make Cowards of vs all,
And thus the Natiue hew of Reſolution
Is ſicklied o’re, with the pale caſt of Thought,
And enterprizes of great pith and moment,
With this regard their Currants turne away,
And looſe the name of Aƈtion. Soft you now,
The faire Ophelia? Nimph, in thy Orizons
Be all my ſinnes remembred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord,
How dœs your Honor for this many a day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly thanke you: well, well, well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I haue Remembrances of yours,
That I haue longed long to re-deliuer.
I pray you now, receiue them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, I neuer gaue you ought.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: My honor’d Lord, I know right well you did,
And with them words of ſo ſweet breath compos’d,
As made the things more rich, then perfume left:
Take theſe againe, for to the Noble minde
Rich gifts wax poore, when giuers proue vnkinde.
There my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha, ha: Are you honeſt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Are you faire?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes your Lordſhip?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That if you be honeſt and faire, your Honeſty
should admit no diſcourſe to your Beautie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Could Beautie my Lord, haue better Comerce
then your Honeſtie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I trulie: for the power of Beautie, will ſooner
tranſforme Honeſtie from what is, to a Bawd, then the
force of Honeſtie can tranſlate Beautie into his likeneſſe.
This was ſometime a Paradox, but now the time giues it
proofe. I did loue you once.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed my Lord, you made me beleeue ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhould not haue beleeued me. For vertue
cannot ſo innocculate our old ſtocke, but we ſhall relliſh
of it. I loued you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I was the more deceiued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Get thee to a Nunnerie. Why would’ſt thou
be a breeder of Sinners? I am my ſelfe indifferent honeſt,
but yet I could accuſe me of ſuch things, that it were bet-
ter my Mother had not borne me. I am very prowd, re-
uengefull, Ambitious, with more offences at my becke,
then I haue thoughts to put them in imagination, to giue
them ſhape, or time to aƈte them in. What ſhould ſuch
Fellowes as I do, crawling betweene Heauen and Earth.
We are arrant Knaues all, beleeue none of vs. Gœ thy
wayes to a Nunnery. Where’s your Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: At home, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Let the doores be ſhut vpon him, that he may
play the Foole no way, but in’s owne houſe. Farewell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: O helpe him, you ſweet Heauens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: If thou dœſt Marry, Ile giue thee this Plague
for thy Dowrie. Be thou as chaſt as Ice, as pure as Snow,
thou ſhalt not eſcape Calumny. Get thee to a Nunnery.
Go, Farewell. Or if thou wilt needs Marry, marry a fool:
for Wiſe men know well enough, what monſters you
make of them. To a Nunnery go, and quickly too. Far-
well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: O heauenly Powers, reſtore him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue heard of your pratlings too wel enough.
God has giuen you one pace,and you make your ſelfe an-
other:you gidge, you amble,and you liſpe, and nickname
Gods creatures, and make your Wantonneſſe, your Ig-
norance.Go too, Ile no more on’t, it hath made me mad.
I ſay, we will haue no more Marriages. Thoſe that are
married already, all but one ſhall liue, the reſt ſhall keep
as they are. To a Nunnery, go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: O what a Noble minde is heere o’re-throwne?
The Courtiers, Soldiers, Schollers: Eye, tongue, ſword,
Th’expeƈtanſie and Roſe of the faire State,
The glaſſe of Faſhion, and the mould of Forme,
Th’obſeru’d of all Obſeruers, quite,quite downe.
Haue I of Ladies moſt deieƈt and wretched,
That ſuck’d the Honie of his Muſicke Vowes:
Now ſee that Noble, and moſt Soueraigne Reaſon,
Like ſweet Bels iangled out of tune, and harſh,
That vnmatch’d Forme and Feature of blowne youth,
Blaſted with extaſie. Oh wœ is me,
T’haue ſeene what I haue ſeene: ſee what I ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Loue? His affeƈtions do not that way tend,
Nor what he ſpake, though it lack’d Forme a little,
Was not like Madneſſe. There’s ſomething in his ſoule?
O’re which his Melancholly ſits on brood,
And I do doubt the hatch, and the diſcloſe
Will be ſome danger, which to preuent
I haue in quicke determination
Thus ſet it downe. He ſhall with ſpeed to England
For the demand of our negleƈted Tribute:
Haply the Seas and Countries different
With variable Obieƈts, ſhall expell
This ſomething ſetled matter in his heart:
Whereon his Braines ſtill beating, puts him thus
From faſhion of himſelfe. What thinke you on’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall do well. But yet do I beleeue
The Origin and Commencement of this greefe
Sprung from negleƈted loue. How now Ophelia?
You neede not tell vs, what Lord Hamlet ſaide,
We heard it all. My Lord, do as you pleaſe,
But if you hold it fit after the Play,
Let his Queene Mother all alone intreat him
To ſhew his Greefes: let her be round with him,
And Ile be plac’d ſo, pleaſe you in the eare
Of all their Conference. If ſhe finde him not,
To England ſend him: Or confine him where
Your wiſedome beſt ſhall thinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: It ſhall be ſo:
Madneſſe in great Ones, muſt not vnwatch’d go.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hamlet, and two or three of the Players.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake the Speech I pray you, as I pronounc’d
it to you trippingly on the Tongue: But if you mouth it,
as many of your Players do, I had as liue the Town-Cryer
had ſpoke my Lines: Nor do not ſaw the Ayre too much
your hand thus, but vſe all gently; for in the verie Tor-
rent, Tempeſt, and (as I may ſay) the Whirle-winde of
Paſſion, you muſt acquire and beget a Temperance that
may giue it Smoothneſſe. O it offends mee to the Soule,
to ſee a robuſtious Pery-wig-pated Fellow,teare a Paſſi-
on to tatters, to verie ragges, to ſplit the eares of the
Groundlings: who (for the moſt part) are capeable of
nothing,but inexplicable dumbe ſhewes,& noiſe: I could
haue ſuch a Fellow whipt for o’re-doing Termagant: it
out-Herod’s Herod. Pray you auoid it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Player.
SPEECH.LINE: I warrant your Honor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Be not too tame neyther: but let your owne
Diſcretion be your Tutor. Sute the Aƈtion to the Word,
the Word to the Aƈtion, with this ſpeciall obſeruance:
That you ore-ſtop not the modeſtie of Nature; for any
thing ſo ouer-done, is frō the purpoſe of Playing, whoſe
end both at the firſt and now, was and is, to hold as ’twer
the Mirrour vp to Nature; to ſhew Vertue her owne
Feature, Scorne her owne Image, and the verie Age and
Bodie of the Time, his forme and preſſure. Now, this
ouer-done, or come tardie off, though it make the vnskil-
full laugh, cannot but make the Iudicious greeue; The
cenſure of the which One, muſt in your allowance o’re-way
a whole Theater of Others. Oh, there bee Players
that I haue ſeene Play, and heard others praiſe, and that
highly (not to ſpeake it prophanely) that neyther hauing
the accent of Chriſtians, nor the gate of Chriſtian, Pagan,
or Norman, haue ſo ſtrutted and bellowed, that I haue
thought ſome of Natures Iouerney-men had made men,
and not made them well, they imitated Humanity ſo ab-
hominably.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Play.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope we haue reform’d that indifferently with
vs, Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: O reforme it altogether. And let thoſe that
play your Clownes,ſpeake no more then is ſet downe for
them. For there be of them, that will themſelues laugh,
to ſet on ſome quantitie of barren Speƈtators to laugh
too, though in the meane time, ſome neceſſary Queſtion
of the Play be then to be conſidered: that’s Villanous, &
shewes a moſt pittifull Ambition in the Foole that vſes
it. Go make you readie.
How now my Lord,
Will the King heare this peece of Worke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: And the Queene too, and that preſently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham
SPEECH.LINE: Bid the Players make haſt.
Will you two helpe to haſten them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: We will my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa, Horatio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ſweet Lord, at your Seruice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Horatio, thou art eene as iuſt a man
As ere my Conuerſation coap’d withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: O my deere Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, do not thinke I flatter:
For what aduancement may I hope from thee,
That no Reuennew haſt, but thy good ſpirits
To feed & cloath thee. Why ſhold the poor be flatter’d?
No, let the Candied tongue, like abſurd pompe,
And crooke the pregnant Hindges of the knee,
Where thrift may follow faining? Doſt thou heare,
Since my deere Soule was Miſtris of my choyſe,
And could of men diſtinguiſh, her eleƈtion
Hath ſeal’d thee for her ſelfe. For thou haſt bene
As one in ſuffering all, that ſuffers nothing.
A man that Fortunes buffets, and Rewards
Hath ’tane with equall Thankes. And bleſt are thoſe,
Whoſe Blood and Iudgement are ſo well co-mingled,
That they are not a Pipe for Fortunes finger.
To ſound what ſtop ſhe pleaſe. Giue me that man,
That is not Paſſions Slaue, and I will weare him
In my hearts Core. I, in my Heart of heart,
As I do thee. Something too much of this.
There is a Play to night to before the King.
One Scœne of it comes neere the Circumſtance
Which I haue told thee, of my Fathers death.
I prythee, when thou ſee’ſt that Aƈte a-foot,
Euen with the verie Comment of my Soule
Obſerue mine Vnkle: If his occulted guilt,
Do not it ſelfe vnkennell in one ſpeech,
It is a damned Ghoſt that we haue ſeene:
And my Imaginations are as foule
As Vulcans Stythe. Giue him needfull note,
For I mine eyes will riuet to his Face:
And after we will both our iudgements ioyne,
To cenſure of his ſeeming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: Well my Lord.
If he ſteale ought the whil’ſt this Play is Playing,
And ſcape deteƈting, I will pay the Theft.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter King, Queene, Polonius, Ophelia, Roſincrance, Guildenſterne, and other Lords attendant with his Guard carrying Torches. Daniſh March. Sound a Flouriſh

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: They are comming to the Play: I muſt be idle.
Get you a place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: How fares our Coſin Hamlet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Excellent Ifaith, of the Camelions diſh: I eate
the Ayre promiſe-cramm’d, you cannot feed Capons ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue nothing with this anſwer Hamlet, theſe
words are not mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nor mine. Now my Lord,you plaid once
i’th’Vniuerſity, you ſay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: That I did my Lord, and was accounted a good
Aƈtor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: And what did you enaƈt?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: I did enaƈt Iulius Cæſar, I was kill’d i’th’Capitol:
Brutus kill’d me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It was a bruite part of him, to kill ſo Capitall a
Calfe there. Be the Players ready?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord, they ſtay vpon your patience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Come hither my good Hamlet, ſit by me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ha.
SPEECH.LINE: No good Mother, here’s Mettle more attraƈtiue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ho, do you marke that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ladie, ſhall I lye in your Lap?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane, my Head vpon your Lap?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you thinke I meant Country matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke nothing, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s a faire thought to ly betweene Maids legs

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: What is my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: You are merrie, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Who I?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh God, your onely Iigge-maker:what ſhould
a man do, but be merrie. For looke you how cheereful-
ly my Mother lookes, and my Father dyed within’s two
Houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, ’tis twice two moneths, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: So long? Nay then let the Diuel weare blacke,
for Ile haue a ſuite of Sables. Oh Heauens! dye two mo-
neths ago, and not forgotten yet? Then there’s hope, a
great mans Memorie, may out-liue his life halfe a yeare:
But byrlady he muſt builde Churches then: or elſe ſhall
he ſuffer not thinking on, with the Hoby-horſſe, whoſe
Epitaph is, For o, For o, the Hoby-horſe is forgot.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Hoboyes play. The dumbe ſhew enters.

Enter a King and Queene, very louingly; the Queene embracing him. She kneeles, and makes ſhew of Proteſtation vnto him. He takes her vp, and declines his head vpon her neck. Layes him downe vpon a Banke of Flowers. She ſeeing him a-ſleepe, leaues him. Anon comes in a Fellow, takes off his Crowne, kiſſes it,and powres poyſon in the Kings eares, and Exits. The Queene returnes, findes the King dead, and makes paſſionate Aƈtion. The Poyſoner, with ſome two or three Mutes comes in againe, ſeeming to lament with her. The dead body is carried away: The Poyſoner Woœs the Queene with Gifts, ſhe ſeemes loath and vnwilling awhile,but in the end,accepts his loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: What meanes this, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry this is Miching Malicho, that meanes
Miſcheefe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Belike this ſhew imports the Argument of the
Play?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall know by theſe Fellowes: the Players
cannot keepe counſell, they’l tell all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Will they tell vs what this ſhew meant?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I, or any ſhew that you’l ſhew him. Bee not
you aſham’d to ſhew, hee’l not ſhame to tell you what it
meanes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: You are naught, you are naught, Ile marke the
Play.
For vs, and for our Tragedie,
Heere ſtooping to your Clemencie:
We begge your hearing Patientlie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Is this a Prologue, or the Pœſie of a Ring?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis briefe my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: As Womans loue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Full thirtie times hath Phœbus Cart gon round,
Neptunes ſalt Waſh, and Tellus Orbed ground:
And thirtie dozen Moones with borrowed ſheene,
About the World haue times twelue thirties beene,
Since loue our hearts, and Hymen did our hands
Vnite comutuall, in moſt ſacred Bands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: So many iournies may the Sunne and Moone
Make vs againe count o’re, ere loue be done.
But wœ is me, you are ſo ſicke of late,
So farre from cheere, and from your former ſtate,
That I diſtruſt you: yet though I diſtruſt,
Diſcomfort you (my Lord) it nothing muſt:
For womens Feare and Loue, holds quantitie,
In neither ought, or in extremity:
Now what my loue is, proofe hath made you know,
And as my Loue is ſiz’d, my Feare is ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith I muſt leaue thee Loue, and ſhortly too:
My operant Powers my Funƈtions leaue to do:
And thou ſhalt liue in this faire world behinde,
Honour’d, belou’d, and haply, one as kinde.
For Husband ſhalt thou—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh confound the reſt:
Such Loue, muſt needs be Treaſon in my breſt:
In ſecond Husband, let me be accurſt,
None wed the ſecond, but who kill’d the firſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Wormwood, Wormwood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bapt.
SPEECH.LINE: The inſtances that ſecond Marriage moue,
Are baſe reſpeƈts of Thrift, but none of Loue.
A ſecond time, I kill my Husband dead,
When ſecond Husband kiſſes me in Bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I do beleeue you. Think what now you ſpeak:
But what we do determine, oft we breake:
Purpoſe is but the ſlaue to Memorie,
Of violent Birth, but poore validitie:
Which now like Fruite vnripe ſtickes on the Tree,
But fall vnſhaken, when they mellow bee.
Moſt neceſſary ’tis, that we forget
To pay our ſelues, what to our ſelues is debt:
What to our ſelues in paſſion we propoſe,
The paſſion ending, doth the purpoſe loſe.
The violence of other Greefe or Ioy,
Their owne ennaƈtors with themſelues deſtroy:
Where Ioy moſt Reuels, Greefe doth moſt lament;
Greefe ioyes, Ioy greeues on ſlender accident.
This world is not for aye, nor ’tis not ſtrange
That euen our Loues ſhould with our Fortunes change.
For ’tis a queſtion left vs yet to proue,
Whether Loue lead Fortune, or elſe Fortune Loue.
The great man downe, you marke his fauourites flies,
The poore aduanc’d, makes Friends of Enemies:
And hitherto doth Loue on Fortune tend,
For who not needs, ſhall neuer lacke a Frend:
And who in want a hollow Friend doth try,
Direƈtly ſeaſons him his Enemie.
But orderly to end, where I begun,
Our Willes and Fates do ſo contrary run,
That our Deuices ſtill are ouerthrowne,
Our thoughts are ours, their ends none of our owne.
So thinke thou wilt no ſecond Husband wed.
But die thy thoughts, when thy firſt Lord is dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bap.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor Earth to giue me food, nor Heauen light,
Sport and repoſe locke from me day and night:
Each oppoſite that blankes the face of ioy,
Meet what I would haue well,and it deſtroy:
Both heere,and hence, purſue me laſting ſtrife,
If once a Widdow, euer I be Wiſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſhe ſhould breake it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis deepely ſworne:
Sweet, leaue me heere a while,
My ſpirits grow dull, and faine I would beguile
The tedious day with ſleepe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Sleepe rocke thy Braine, Sleepes
And neuer come miſchance betweene vs twaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, how like you this Play?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: The Lady proteſts to much me thinkes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh but ſhee’l keepe her word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you heard the Argument, is there no Of-
fence in’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, they do but ieſt, poyſon in ieſt, no Of-
fence i’th’world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What do you call the Play?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The Mouſe-trap: Marry how? Tropically:
This Play is the Image of a murder done in Vienna: Gon-
zago is the Dukes name, his wife Baptiſta: you ſhall ſee
anon: ’tis a knauiſh peece of worke: But what o’that?
Your Maieſtie, and wee that haue free ſoules, it touches
vs not: let the gall’d iade winch:our withers are vnrung.
This is one Lucianus nephew to the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: You are a good Chorus, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I could interpret betweene you and your loue:
if I could ſee the Puppets dallying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: You are keene my Lord, you are keene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It would coſt you a groaning, to take off my
edge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Still better and worſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: So you miſtake Husbands.
Begin Murderer. Pox, leaue thy damnable Faces, and
begin. Come,the croaking Rauen doth bellow for Re-
uenge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lucian.
SPEECH.LINE: Thoughts blacke, hands apt,
Drugges fit, and Time agreeing:
Confederate ſeaſon, elſe, no Creature ſeeing:
Thou mixture ranke, of Midnight Weeds colleƈted,
With Hecats Ban, thrice blaſted, thrice infeƈted,
Thy naturall Magicke,and dire propertie,
On wholſome life, vſurpe immediately.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Powres the poyſon in his eares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: He poyſons him i’th’Garden for’s eſtate: His
name’s Gonzago: the Story is extant and writ in choyce
Italian. You ſhall ſee anon how the Murtherer gets the
loue of Gonzago’s wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: The King riſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What, frighted with falſe fire.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How fares my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue o’re the Play.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me ſome Light. Away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All
SPEECH.LINE: Lights, Lights, Lights.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why let the ſtrucken Deere go weepe,
The Hart vngalled play:
For ſome muſt watch, while ſome muſt ſleepe;
So runnes the world away.
Would not this Sir, and a Forreſt of Feathers,if the reſt of
my Fortunes turne Turke with me; with two Prouinciall
Roſes on my rac’d Shoœs, get me a Fellowſhip in a crie
of Players ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Halfe a ſhare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A whole one I,
For thou doſt know: Oh Damon deere,
This Realme diſmantled was of Ioue himſelfe,
And now reignes heere.
A verie verie Paiocke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: You might haue Rim’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh good Horatio, Ile take the Ghoſts word for
a thouſand pound. Did’ſt perceiue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie well my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon the talke of the poyſoning?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: I did verie well note him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh,ha? Come ſome Muſick.Come ý Recorders:
For if the King like not the Comedie,
Why then belike he likes it not perdie.
Come ſome Muſicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord, vouchſafe me a word with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, a whole Hiſtory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: The King, ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir, what of him?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Is in his retyrement, maruellous diſtemper’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: With drinke Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: No my Lord, rather with choller.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Your wiſedome ſhould ſhew it ſelfe more ri-
cher, to ſignifie this to his Doƈtor: for for me to put him
to his Purgation, would perhaps plundge him into farre
more Choller.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord put your diſcourſe into ſome
frame, and ſtart not ſo wildely from my affayre.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I am tame Sir, pronounce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: The Queene your Mother, in moſt great affli-
ƈtion of ſpirit, hath ſent me to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: You are welcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good my Lord, this courteſie is not of
the right breed. If it ſhall pleaſe you to make me a whol-
ſome anſwer, I will dœ your Mothers command’ment:
if not, your pardon, and my returne ſhall bee the end of
my Buſineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: What, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Make you a wholſome anſwere: my wits diſ-
eas’d. But ſir, ſuch anſwers as I can make, you ſhal com-
mand: or rather you ſay, my Mother: therfore no more
but to the matter. My Mother you ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Then thus ſhe ſayes: your behauior hath ſtroke
her into amazement, and admiration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh wonderfull Sonne, that can ſo aſtoniſh a
Mother. But is there no ſequell at the heeles of this Mo-
thers admiration?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: She deſires to ſpeake with you in her Cloſſet,
ere you go to bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhall obey, were ſhe ten times our Mother.
Haue you any further Trade with vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, you once did loue me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: So I do ſtill, by theſe pickers and ſtealers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord, what is your cauſe of diſtem-
per? You do freely barre the doore of your owne Liber-
tie, if you deny your greefes to your Friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir I lacke Aduancement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: How can that be,when you haue the voyce of
the King himſelfe, for your Succeſſion in Denmarke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I,but while the graſſe growes, the Prouerbe is
something muſty.
O the Recorder. Let me ſee, to withdraw with you, why
do you go about to recouer the winde of mee, as if you
would driue me into a toyle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: O my Lord, if my Dutie be too bold,my loue
is too vnmannerly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not well vnderſtand that. Will you play
vpon this Pipe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, I cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue me, I cannot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I do beſeech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: I know no touch of it, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis as eaſie as lying: gouerne theſe Ventiges
with your finger and thumbe, giue it breath with your
mouth, and it will diſcourſe moſt excellent Muſicke.
Looke you, theſe are the ſtoppes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: But theſe cannot I command to any vtterance
of hermony, I haue not the ſkill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why looke you now, how vnworthy a thing
you make of me: you would play vpon mee; you would
seeme to know my ſtops: you would pluck out the heart
of my Myſterie; you would ſound mee from my loweſt
Note,to the top of my Compaſſe: and there is much Mu-
ſicke, excellent Voice, in this little Organe, yet cannot
you make it. Why do you thinke, that I am eaſier to bee
plaid on, then a Pipe? Call me what Inſtrument you will,
though you can fret me, you cannot play vpon me. God
bleſſe you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord; the Queene would ſpeak with you,
and preſently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you ſee that Clowd? that’s almoſt in ſhape
like a Camell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: By’th’Miſſe, and it’s like a Camell indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Me thinkes it is like a Weazell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: It is back’d like a Weazell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Or like a Whale?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie like a Whale.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Then will I come to my Mother, by and by:
They foole me to the top of my bent.
I will come by and by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Polon
SPEECH.LINE: I will ſay ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: By and by, is eaſily ſaid. Leaue me Friends:
’Tis now the verie witching time of night,
When Churchyards yawne, and Hell it ſelfe breaths out
Contagion to this world. Now could I drink hot blood,
And do ſuch bitter buſineſſe as the day
Would quake to looke on. Soft now,to my Mother:
Oh Heart, looſe not thy Nature; let not euer
The Soule of Nero, enter this firme boſome:
Let me be cruell, not vnnaturall,
I will ſpeake Daggers to her, but vſe none:
My Tongue and Soule in this be Hypocrites.
How in my words ſomeuer ſhe be ſhent,
To giue them Seales, neuer my Soule conſent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I like him not, nor ſtands it ſafe with vs,
To let his madneſſe range. Therefore prepare you,
I your Commiſſion will forthwith diſpatch,
And he to England ſhall along with you:
The termes of our eſtate, may not endure
Hazard ſo dangerous as doth hourely grow
Out of his Lunacies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: We will our ſelues prouide:
Moſt holie and Religious feare it is
To keepe thoſe many many bodies ſafe
That liue and feede vpon your Maieſtie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſingle
And peculiar life is bound
With all the ſtrength and Armour of the minde,
To keepe it ſelfe from noyance: but much more,
That Spirit, vpon whoſe ſpirit depends and reſts
The liues of many, the ceaſe of Maieſtie
Dies not alone; but like a Gulfe doth draw
What’s neere it, with it. It is a maſſie wheele
Fixt on the Somnet of the higheſt Mount.
To whoſe huge Spoakes, ten thouſand leſſer things
Are mortiz’d and adioyn’d: which when it falles,
Each ſmall annexment, pettie conſequence
Attends the boyſtrous Ruine. Neuer alone
Did the King ſighe, but with a generall grone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Arme you, I pray you to this ſpeedie Voyage;
For we will Fetters put vpon this feare,
Which now gœs too free-footed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Both
SPEECH.LINE: We will haſte vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, he’s going to his Mothers Cloſſet:
Behinde the Arras Ile conuey my ſelfe
To heare the Proceſſe. Ile warrant ſhee’l tax him home,
And as you ſaid, and wiſely was it ſaid,
’Tis meete that ſome more audience then a Mother,
Since Nature makes them partiall, ſhould o’re-heare
The ſpeech of vantage. Fare you well my Liege,
Ile call vpon you ere you go to bed,
And tell you what I know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thankes deere my Lord.
Oh my offence is ranke, it ſmels to heauen,
It hath the primall eldeſt curſe vpon’t,
A Brothers murther. Pray can I not,
Though inclination be as ſharpe as will:
My ſtronger guilt, defeats my ſtrong intent,
And like a man to double buſineſſe bound,
I ſtand in pauſe where I ſhall firſt begin,
And both negleƈt; what if this curſed hand
Were thicker then it ſelfe with Brothers blood,
Is there not Raine enough in the ſweet Heauens
To waſh it white as Snow? Whereto ſerues mercy,
But to confront the viſage of Offence?
And what’s in Prayer, but this two-fold force,
To be fore-ſtalled ere we come to fall,
Or pardon’d being downe? Then Ile looke vp,
My fault is paſt. But oh, what forme of Prayer
Can ſerue my turne? Forgiue me my foule Murther:
That cannot be, ſince I am ſtill poſſeſt
Of thoſe effeƈts for which I did the Murther.
My Crowne, mine owne Ambition, and my Queene:
May one be pardon’d, and retaine th’offence?
In the corrupted currants of this world,
Offences gilded hand may ſhoue by Iuſtice,
And oft ’tis ſeene, the wicked prize it ſelfe
Buyes out the Law; but ’tis not ſo aboue,
There is no ſhuffling, there the Aƈtion lyes
In his true Nature, and we our ſelues compell’d
Euen to the teeth and forehead of our faults,
To giue in euidence. What then? What reſts?
Try what Repentance can. What can it not?
Yet what can it, when one cannot repent?
Oh wretched ſtate! Oh boſome, blacke as death!
Oh limed ſoule, that ſtrugling to be free,
Art more ingag’d: Helpe Angels, make aſſay:
Bow ſtubborne knees, and heart with ſtrings of Steele,
Be ſoft as ſinewes of the new-borne Babe,
All may be well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Now might I do it pat, now he is praying,
And now Ile doo’t, and ſo he gœs to Heauen,
And ſo am I reueng’d: that would be ſcann’d,
A Villaine killes my Father, and for that
I his foule Sonne, do this ſame Villaine ſend
To heauen. Oh this is hyre and Sallery,not Reuenge.
He tooke my Father groſſely, full of bread,
With all his Crimes broad blowne, as freſh as May,
And how his Audit ſtands, who knowes,ſaue Heauen:
But in our circumſtance and courſe of thought
’Tis heauie with him: and am I then reueng’d,
To take him in the purging of his Soule,
When he is fit and ſeaſon’d for his paſſage? No.
Vp Sword, and know thou a more horrid hent
When he is drunke aſleepe: or in his Rage,
Or in th’inceſtuous pleaſure of his bed,
At gaming, ſwearing, or about ſome aƈte
That ha’s no relliſh of Saluation in’t,
Then trip him, that his heeles may kicke at Heauen,
And that his Soule may be as damn’d and blacke
As Hell, whereto it gœs. My Mother ſtayes,
This Phyſicke but prolongs thy ſickly dayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: My words flye vp, my thoughts remain below,
Words without thoughts, neuer to Heauen go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: He will come ſtraight:
Looke you lay home to him,
Tell him his prankes haue been too broad to beare with,
And that your Grace hath ſcreen’d,and ſtoode betweene
Much heate, and him. Ile ſilence me e’ene heere:
Pray you be round with him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham. within.
SPEECH.LINE: Mother, mother, mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile warrant you, feare me not.
Withdraw, I heare him comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Mother, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Hamlet, thou haſt thy Father much offended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Mother, you haue my Father much offended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, you anſwer with an idle tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Go, go, you queſtion with an idle tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Why how now Hamlet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Whats the matter now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue you forgot me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No by the Rood, not ſo:
You are the Queene, your Husbands Brothers wife,
But would you were not ſo. You are my Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, then Ile ſet thoſe to you that can ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, come, and ſit you downe, you ſhall not
boudge:
You go not till I ſet you vp a glaſſe,
Where you may ſee the inmoſt part of you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What wilt thou do? thou wilt not murther me?
Helpe, helpe, hoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol.
SPEECH.LINE: What hoa,helpe,helpe, helpe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How now, a Rat? dead for a Ducate,dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pol
SPEECH.LINE: Oh I am ſlaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh me, what haſt thou done?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay I know not, is it the King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh what a raſh, and bloody deed is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A bloody deed, almoſt as bad good Mother,
As kill a King, and marrie with his Brother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: As kill a King?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I Lady, ’twas my word.
Thou wretched, raſh, intruding foole farewell,
I tooke thee for thy Betters, take thy Fortune,
Thou find’ſt to be too buſie,is ſome danger.
Leaue wringing of your hands, peace, ſit you downe,
And let me wring your heart, for ſo I ſhall
If it be made of penetrable ſtuffe;
If damned Cuſtome haue not braz’d it ſo,
That it is proofe and bulwarke againſt Senſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What haue I done, that thou dar’ſt wag thy tong,
In noiſe ſo rude againſt me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Such an Aƈt
That blurres the grace and bluſh of Modeſtie,
Cals Vertue Hypocrite, takes off the Roſe
From the faire forehead of an innocent loue,
And makes a bliſter there. Makes marriage vowes
As falſe as Dicers Oathes. Oh ſuch a deed,
As from the body of Contraƈtion pluckes
The very ſoule, and ſweete Religion makes
A rapſidie of words. Heauens face doth glow,
Yea this ſolidity and compound maſſe,
With triſtfull viſage as againſt the doome,
Is thought-sicke at the aƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Aye me; what aƈt, that roares ſo lowd, & thun-
ders in the Index.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke heere vpon this Piƈture, and on this,
The counterfet preſentment of two Brothers:
See what a grace was ſeated on his Brow,
Hyperions curles, the front of Ioue himſelfe,
An eye like Mars, to threaten or command
A Station, like the Herald Mercurie
New lighted on a heauen-kiſſing hill:
A Combination, and a forme indeed,
Where euery God did ſeeme to ſet his Seale,
To giue the world aſſurance of a man.
This was your Husband. Looke you now what followes.
Heere is your Husband, like a Mildew’d eare
Blaſting his wholſom breath. Haue you eyes?
Could you on this faire Mountaine leaue to feed,
And batten on this Moore? Ha? Haue you eyes?
You cannot call it Loue: For at your age,
The hey-day in the blood is tame, it’s humble,
And waites vpon the Iudgement: and what Iudgement
Would ſtep from this, to this? What diuell was’t,
That thus hath couſend you at hoodman-blinde?
O Shame! where is thy Bluſh? Rebellious Hell,
If thou canſt mutine in a Matrons bones,
To flaming youth, let Vertue be as waxe.
And melt in her owne fire. Proclaime no ſhame,
When the compulſiue Ardure giues the charge,
Since Froſt it ſelfe, as aƈtiuely doth burne,
As Reaſon panders Will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: O Hamlet, ſpeake no more.
Thou turn’ſt mine eyes into my very ſoule,
And there I ſee ſuch blacke and grained ſpots,
As will not leaue their Tinƈt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but to liue
In the ranke ſweat of an enſeamed bed,
Stew’d in Corruption; honying and making loue
Ouer the naſty Stye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh ſpeake to me,no more,
Theſe words like Daggers enter in mine eares.
No more ſweet Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A Murderer,and a Villaine:
A Slaue, that is not twentieth part the tythe
Of your precedent Lord. A vice of Kings,
A Cutpurſe of the Empire and the Rule.
That from a ſhelfe,the precious Diadem ſtole,
And put it in his Pocket.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: No more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: A King of ſhreds and patches.
Saue me; and houer o’re me with your wings
You heauenly Guards. What would your gracious figure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas he’s mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you not come your tardy Sonne to chide,
That laps’t in Time and Paſſion, lets go by
Th’important aƈting of your dread command? Oh ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ghoſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not forget: this Viſitation
Is but to whet thy almoſt blunted purpoſe.
But looke, Amazement on thy Mother ſits;
O ſtep betweene her, and her fighting Soule,
Conceit in weakeſt bodies, ſtrongeſt workes.
Speake to her Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How is it with you Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, how is’t with you?
That you bend your eye on vacancie,
And with their corporall ayre do hold diſcourſe.
Forth at your eyes, your ſpirits wildely peepe,
And as the ſleeping Soldiours in th’Alarme,
Your bedded haire, like life in excrements,
Start vp, and ſtand an end. Oh gentle Sonne,
Vpon the heate and flame of thy diſtemper
Sprinkle coole patience. Whereon do you looke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: On him, on him: look you how pale he glares,
His forme and cauſe conioyn’d, preaching to ſtones,
Would make them capeable. Do not looke vpon me,
Leaſt with this pitteous aƈtion you conuert
My ſterne effeƈts: then what I haue to do,
Will want true colour; teares perchance for blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: To who do you ſpeake this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you ſee nothing there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing at all, yet all that is I ſee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor did you nothing heare?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: No, nothing but our ſelues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why look you there: looke how it ſteals away:
My Father in his habite, as he liued,
Looke where he gœs euen now out at the Portall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: This is the very coynage of your Braine,
This bodileſſe Creation extaſie is very cunning in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Extaſie?
My Pulſe as yours doth temperately keepe time,
And makes as healthfull Muſicke. It is not madneſſe
That I haue vttered; bring me to the Teſt
And I the matter will re-word: which madneſſe
Would gamboll from. Mother, for loue of Grace,
Lay not a flattering Vnƈtion to your ſoule,
That not your treſpaſſe, but my madneſſe ſpeakes:
It will but ſkin and filme the Vlcerous place,
Whil’ſt ranke Corruption mining all within,
Infeƈts vnſeene. Confeſſe your ſelfe to Heauen,
Repent what’s paſt, auoyd what is to come,
And do not ſpred the Compoſt on the Weedes,
To make them ranke. Forgiue me this my Vertue,
For in the fatneſſe of this purſie times,
Vertue it ſelfe, of Vice muſt pardon begge,
Yea courb, and wœ, for leaue to do him good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Hamlet,
Thou haſt cleft my heart in twaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: O throw away the worſer part of it,
And liue the purer with the other halfe.
Good night, but go not to mine Vnkles bed,
Aſſume a Vertue, if you haue it not, refraine to night,
And that ſhall lend a kinde of eaſineſſe
To the next abſtinence. Once more goodnight,
And when you are deſirous to be bleſt,
Ile bleſſing begge of you. For this ſame Lord,
I do repent: but heauen hath pleas’d it ſo,
To puniſh me with this, and this with me,
That I muſt be their Scourge and Miniſter.
I will beſtow him, and will anſwer well
The death I gaue him: ſo againe, good night.
I muſt be cruell, onely to be kinde;
Thus bad begins and worſe remaines behinde.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſhall I do?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Not this by no meanes that I bid you do:
Let the blunt King tempt you againe to bed,
Pinch Wanton on your cheeke, call you his Mouſe,
And let him for a paire of reechie kiſſes,
Or padling in your necke with his damn’d Fingers,
Make you to rauell all this matter out,
That I eſſentially am not in madneſſe,
But made in craft. ’Twere good you let him know,
For who that’s but a Queene, faire, ſober, wiſe,
Would from a Paddocke, from a Bat,a Gibbe,
Such deere concernings hide, Who would do ſo,
No in deſpight of Senſe and Secrecie,
Vnpegge the Basket on the houſes top:
Let the Birds flye, and like the famous Ape
To try Concluſions in the Basket, creepe
And breake your owne necke downe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Be thou aſſur’d, if words be made of breath,
And breath of life: I haue no life to breath
What thou haſt ſaide to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I muſt to England, you know that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke I had forgot: ’Tis ſo concluded on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: This man ſhall ſet me packing:
Ile lugge the Guts into the Neighbor roome,
Mother goodnight. Indeede this Counſellor
Is now moſt ſtill, moſt ſecret, and moſt graue,
Who was in life, a fooliſh prating Knaue.
Come ſir, to draw toward an end with you.
Good night Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s matters in theſe ſighes.
Theſe profound heaues
You muſt tranſlate; Tis fit we vnderſtand them.
Where is your Sonne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Ah my good Lord, what haue I ſeene to night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What Gertrude? How do’s Hamlet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Mad as the Seas, and winde, when both contend
Which is the Mightier, in his lawleſſe fit
Behinde the Arras, hearing ſomething ſtirre,
He whips his Rapier out, and cries a Rat, a Rat,
And in his brainiſh apprehenſion killes
The vnſeene good old man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh heauy deed:
It had bin ſo with vs had we beene there:
His Liberty is full of threats to all,
To you your ſelfe, to vs, to euery one.
Alas,how ſhall this bloody deede be anſwered?
It will be laide to vs, whoſe prouidence
Should haue kept ſhort, reſtrain’d,and out of haunt,
This mad yong man. But ſo much was our loue,
We would not vnderſtand what was moſt fit,
But like the Owner of a foule diſeaſe,
To keepe it from divulging, let’s it feede
Euen on the pith of life. Where is he gone?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: To draw apart the body he hath kild,
O’re whom his very madneſſe like ſome Oare
Among a Minerall of Mettels baſe
Shewes it ſelfe pure. He weepes for what is done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Gertrude, come away:
The Sun no ſooner ſhall the Mountaines touch,
But we will ſhip him hence, and this vilde deed,
We muſt with all our Maieſty and Skill
Both countenance, and excuſe.
Ho Guildenſtern:
Friends both go ioyne you with ſome further ayde:
Hamlet in madneſſe hath Polonius ſlaine,
And from his Mother Cloſſets hath he drag’d him.
Go ſeeke him out, ſpeake faire,and bring the body
Into the Chappell. I pray you haſt in this.
Come Gertrude,wee’l call vp our wiſeſt friends,
To let them know both what we meane to do,
And what’s vntimely done. Oh come away,
My ſoule is full of diſcord and diſmay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Safely ſtowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gentlemen within.
SPEECH.LINE: Hamlet, Lord Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What noiſe? Who cals on Hamlet?
Oh heere they come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ro.
SPEECH.LINE: What haue you done my Lord with the dead body?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Compounded it with duſt,whereto ’tis Kinne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Tell vs where ’tis, that we may take it thence,
And beare it to the Chappell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Do not beleeue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Beleeue what?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That I can keepe your counſell, and not mine
owne. Beſides, to be demanded of a Spundge, what re-
plication ſhould be made by the Sonne of a King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Take you me for a Spundge, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſir,that ſokes vp the Kings Countenance, his
Rewards, his Authorities (but ſuch Officers do the King
beſt ſeruice in the end. He keepes them like an Ape in
the corner of his iaw, firſt mouth’d to be laſt ſwallowed,
when he needes what you haue glean’d, it is but ſquee-
zing you, and Spundge you ſhall be dry againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: I vnderſtand you not my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I am glad of it: a knauiſh ſpeech ſleepes in a
fooliſh eare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, you muſt tell vs where the body is,
and go with vs to the King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The body is with the King,but the King is not
with the body. The King, is a thing—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guild.
SPEECH.LINE: A thing my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Of nothing: bring me to him, hide Fox, and all
after.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue ſent to ſeeke him, and to find the bodie:
How dangerous is it that this man gœs looſe:
Yet muſt not we put the ſtrong Law on him:
Hee’s loued of the diſtraƈted multitude,
Who like not in their iudgement, but their eyes:
And where ’tis ſo, th’Offenders ſcourge is weigh’d
But neerer the offence: to beare all ſmooth,and euen,
This ſodaine ſending him away, muſt ſeeme
Deliberate pauſe, diſeaſes deſperate growne,
By deſperate appliance are releeued,
Or not at all.
How now? What hath befalne?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where the dead body is beſtow’d my Lord,
We cannot get from him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: But where is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Without my Lord, guarded to know your
pleaſure.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring him before vs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Roſin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hoa, Guildenſterne? Bring in my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Now Hamlet, where’s Polonius?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: At Supper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: At Supper? Where?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Not where he eats, but where he is eaten, a cer-
taine conuocation of wormes are e’ne at him. Your worm
is your onely Emperor for diet. We fat all creatures elſe
to fat vs, and we fat our ſelfe for Magots. Your fat King,
and your leane Begger is but variable ſeruice to diſhes,
but to one Table that’s the end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What doſt thou meane by this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing but to ſhew you how a King may go
a Progreſſe through the guts of a Begger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is Polonius.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: In heauen, ſend thither to ſee. If your Meſſen-
ger finde him not there, ſeeke him i’th other place your
ſelfe: but indeed, if you finde him not this moneth, you
shall noſe him as you go vp the ſtaires into the Lobby.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſeeke him there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: He will ſtay till ye come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: K.
SPEECH.LINE: Hamlet, this deed of thine, for thine eſpecial ſafety
Which we do tender, as we deerely greeue
For that which thou haſt done, muſt ſend thee hence
With fierie Quickneſſe. Therefore prepare thy ſelfe,
The Barke is readie, and the winde at helpe,
Th’Aſſociates tend, and euery thing at bent
For England.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: For England?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: So is it, if thou knew’ſt our purpoſes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee a Cherube that ſee’s him: but come, for
England. Farewell deere Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy louing Father Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamlet.
SPEECH.LINE: My Mother: Father and Mother is man and
wife: man & wife is one fleſh, and ſo my mother.Come,
for England.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow him at foote,
Tempt him with ſpeed aboord:
Delay it not, Ile haue him hence to night.
Away, for euery thing is Seal’d and done
That elſe leanes on th’Affaire,pray you make haſt.
And England, if my loue thou holdſt at ought,
As my great power thereof may giue thee ſenſe,
Since yet thy Cicatrice lookes raw and red
After the Daniſh Sword, and thy free awe
Payes homage to vs; thou maiſt not coldly ſet
Our Soueraigne Proceſſe, which imports at full
By Letters coniuring to that effeƈt
The preſent death of Hamlet. Do it England,
For like the Heƈticke in my blood he rages,
And thou muſt cure me: Till I know ’tis done,
How ere my happes, my ioyes were ne’re begun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Go Captaine, from me greet the Daniſh King,
Tell him that by his licenſe, Fortinbras
Claimes the conueyance of a promis’d March
Ouer his Kingdome. You know the Rendeuous:
If that his Maieſty would ought with vs,
We ſhall expreſſe our dutie in his eye,
And let him know ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cap.
SPEECH.LINE: I will doo’t, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For
SPEECH.LINE: Go ſafely on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I will not ſpeake with her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: She is importunate, indeed diſtraƈt, her moode
will needs be pittied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: What would ſhe haue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſpeakes much of her Father; ſaies ſhe heares
There’s trickes i’th’world, and hems, and beats her heart,
Spurnes enuiouſly at Strawes, ſpeakes things in doubt,
That carry but halfe ſenſe: Her ſpeech is nothing,
Yet the vnſhaped vſe of it doth moue
The hearers to Colleƈtion; they ayme at it,
And botch the words vp fit to their owne thoughts,
Which as her winkes, and nods, and geſtures yeeld them,
Indeed would make one thinke there would be thought,
Though nothing ſure, yet much vnhappily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twere good ſhe were ſpoken with,
For ſhe may ſtrew dangerous conieƈtures
In ill breeding minds. Let her come in.
To my ſicke ſoule (as ſinnes true Nature is)
Each toy ſeemes Prologue, to ſome great amiſſe,
So full of Artleſſe iealouſie is guilt,
It ſpill’s it ſelfe, in fearing to be ſpilt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the beauteous Maieſty of Denmark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Ophelia?

LINE.ITALIC: How ſhould I your true loue know from another one?

LINE.LINE: By his Cockle hat and ſtaffe, and his Sandal ſhoone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas ſweet Lady: what imports this Song?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Say you? Nay pray you marke.

LINE.ITALIC: He is dead and gone Lady, he is dead and gone,
At his head a graſſe-greene Turfe, at his heeles a ſtone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay but Ophelia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you marke.

LINE.ITALIC: White his Shrow’d as the Mountaine Snow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas, looke heere my Lord.

LINE.ITALIC: Larded with ſweet Flowers:
Which bewept to the graue did not go,
With true-loue ſhowres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: How do ye, pretty Lady?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, God dil’d you. They ſay the Owle was
a Bakers daughter. Lord, wee know what we are, but
know not what we may be. God be at your Table.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Conceit vpon her Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Pray you let’s haue no words of this: but when
they aske you what it meanes,ſay you this:

LINE.ITALIC: Tomorrow is S. Valentines day, all in the morning betime,
And I a Maid at your Window, to be your Valentine.
Then vp he roſe,& don’d his clothes,& dupt the chamber dore,
Let in the Maid,that out a Maid,neuer departed more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Pretty Ophelia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: Indeed la? without an oath Ile make an end ont.

LINE.ITALIC: By gis, and by S. Charity,
Alacke, and fie for ſhame:
Yong men wil doo’t,if they come too’t,
By Cocke they are too blame.
Quoth ſhe before you tumbled me,
You promis’d me to Wed:
So would I ha done by yonder Sunne,
And thou hadſt not come to my bed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: How long hath ſhe bin this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: I hope all will be well. We muſt bee patient,
but I cannot chooſe but weepe, to thinke they ſhould
lay him i’th’cold ground: My brother ſhall knowe of it,
and ſo I thanke you for your good counſell. Come, my
Coach: Goodnight Ladies: Goodnight ſweet Ladies:
Goodnight, goodnight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Follow her cloſe,
Giue her good watch I pray you:
Oh this is the poyſon of deepe greefe, it ſprings
All from her Fathers death. Oh Gertrude, Gertrude,
When ſorrowes comes, they come not ſingle ſpies,
But in Battalines. Firſt,her Father ſlaine,
Next your Sonne gone, and he moſt violent Author
Of his owne iuſt remoue: the people muddied,
Thicke and vnwholſome in their thoughts, and whiſpers
For good Polonius death; and we haue done but greenly
In hugger mugger to interre him. Poore Ophelia
Diuided from her ſelfe, and her faire Iudgement,
Without the which we are Piƈtures,or meere Beaſts.
Laſt, and as much containing as all theſe,
Her Brother is in ſecret come from France,
Keepes on his wonder, keepes himſelfe in clouds,
And wants not Buzzers to infeƈt his eare
With peſtilent Speeches of his Fathers death,
Where in neceſſitie of matter Beggard,
Will nothing ſticke our perſons to Arraigne
In eare and eare. O my deere Gertrude, this,
Like to a murdering Peece in many places,
Giues me ſuperfluous death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Alacke, what noyſe is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Where are my Switzers?
Let them guard the doore. What is the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Saue your ſelfe,my Lord.
The Ocean (ouer-peering of his Liſt)
Eates not the Flats with more impittious haſte
Then young Lærtes, in a Riotous head,
Ore-beares your Officers, the rabble call him Lord,
And as the world were now but to begin,
Antiquity forgot, Cuſtome not knowne,
The Ratifiers and props of euery word,
They cry chooſe we? Lærtes ſhall be King,
Caps, hands, and tongues, applaud it to the clouds,
Lærtes ſhall be King,Lærtes King.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: How cheerefully on the falſe Traile they cry,
Oh this is Counter you falsſe Daniſh Dogges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: The doores are broke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is the King, ſirs? Stand you all without.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: No, let’s come in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you giue me leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Al.
SPEECH.LINE: We will, we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you: Keepe the doore.
Oh thou vilde King, giue me my Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Calmely good Lærtes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: That drop of blood, that calmes
Proclaimes me Baſtard:
Cries Cuckold to my Father, brands the Harlot
Euen heere betweene the chaſte vnſmirched brow
Of my true Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: What is the cauſe Lærtes,
That thy Rebellion lookes ſo Gyant-like?
Let him go Gertrude: Do not feare our perſon:
There’s ſuch Diuinity doth hedge a King,
That Treaſon can but peepe to what it would,
Aƈts little of his will. Tell me Lærtes,
Why thou art thus Incenſt? Let him go Gertrude.
Speake man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Where’s my Father?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: But not by him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him demand his fill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: How came he dead? Ile not be Iuggel’d with.
To hell Allegeance: Vowes, to the blackeſt diuell.
Conſcience and Grace, to the profoundeſt Pit.
I dare Damnation: to this point I ſtand,
That both the worlds I giue to negligence,
Let come what comes: onely Ile be reueng’d
Moſt throughly for my Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Who ſhall ſtay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: My Will, not all the world,
And for my meanes, Ile husband them ſo well,
They ſhall go farre with little.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Lærtes:
If you deſire to know the certaintie
Of your deere Fathers death, if writ in your reuenge,
That Soop-ſtake you will draw both Friend and Fœ,
Winner and Looſer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: None but his Enemies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you know them then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: La.
SPEECH.LINE: To his good Friends, thus wide Ile ope my Armes:
And like the kinde Life-rend’ring Politician,
Repaſt them with my blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Why now you ſpeake
Like a good Childe, and a true Gentleman.
That I am guiltleſſe of your Fathers death,
And am moſt ſenſible in greefe for it,
It ſhall as leuell to your Iudgement pierce
As day do’s to your eye.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: A noiſe within. Let her come in.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: How now? what noiſe is that?
Oh heate drie vp my Braines, teares ſeuen times ſalt,
Burne out the Sence and Vertue of mine eye.
By Heauen, thy madneſſe ſhall be payed by waight,
Till our Scale turnes the beame. Oh Roſe of May,
Deere Maid, kinde Siſter, ſweet Ophelia:
Oh Heauens, is’t poſſible, a yong Maids wits,
Should be as mortall as an old mans life?
Nature is fine in Loue, and where ’tis fine,
It ſends ſome precious inſtance of it ſelfe
After the thing it loues.

LINE.ITALIC: They bore him bare fac’d on the Beer,
Hey non nony, nony, hey nony:
And on his graue raines many a teare,
Fare you well my Doue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Had’ſt thou thy wits, and did’ſt perſwade Re-
uenge, it could not moue thus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: You muſt ſing downe a-downe, and you call
him a-downe-a. Oh, how the wheele becomes it? It is
the falſe Steward that ſtole his maſters daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: This nothings more then matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s Roſemary, that’s for Remembraunce.
Pray loue remember: and there is Paconcies, that’s for
Thoughts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: A document in madneſſe, thoughts & remem-
brance fitted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s Fennell for you, and Columbines: ther’s
Rew for you, and heere’s ſome for me. Wee may call it
Herbe-Grace a Sundaies: Oh you muſt weare your Rew
with a difference. There’s a Dayſie, I would giue you
some Violets, but they wither’d all when my Father dy-
ed: They ſay, he made a good end;

LINE.ITALIC: For bonny ſweet Robin is all my ioy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Thought, and Affliƈtion,Paſſion,Hell it ſelfe:
She turnes to Fauour, and to prettineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ophe.

LINE.ITALIC: And will he not come againe,
And will he not come againe:
No, no, he is dead, go to thy Death-bed,
He neuer wil come againe.
His Beard as white as Snow,
All Flaxen was his Pole:
He is gone, he is gone,and we caſt away mone,
Gramercy on his Soule.

SPEECH.LINE: And of all Chriſtian Soules, I pray God.
God buy ye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you ſee this,you Gods?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Lærtes,I muſt common with your greefe,
Or you deny me right: go but apart,
Make choice of whom your wiſeſt Friends you will,
And they ſhall heare and iudge ’twixt you and me;
If by direƈt or by Colaterall hand
They finde vs touch’d, we will our Kingdome giue,
Our Crowne, our Life,and all that we call Ours
To you in ſatisfaƈtion. But if not,
Be you content to lend your patience to vs,
And we ſhall ioyntly labour with your ſoule
To giue it due content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Let this be ſo:
His meanes of death, his obſcure buriall;
No Trophee, Sword,nor Hatchment o’re his bones,
No Noble rite, nor formall oſtentation,
Cry to be heard, as ’twere from Heauen to Earth,
That I muſt call in queſtion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: So you ſhall:
And where th’offence is, let the great Axe fall.
I pray you go with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: What are they that would ſpeake with me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ser.
SPEECH.LINE: Saylors ſir, they ſay they haue Letters for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Let them come in,
I do not know from what part of the world
I ſhould be greeted, if not from Lord Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Say.
SPEECH.LINE: God bleſſe you Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him bleſſe thee too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Say.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee ſhall Sir, and’t pleaſe him. There’s a Letter
for you Sir: It comes from th’Ambaſſadours that was
bound for England, if your name be Horatio, as I am let
to know it is.
Horatio, When thou ſhalt haue ouerlook’d this, giue theſe

LINE.ITALIC: Fellowes ſome meanes to the King: They haue Letters
for him. Ere we were two dayes old at Sea, a Pyrate of very
Warlicke appointment gaue vs Chace. Finding our ſelues too
slow of Saile, we put on a compelled Valour. In the Grapple, I
boorded them: On the inſtant they got cleare of our Shippe, ſo
I alone became their Priſoner. They haue dealt with mee, like
Theeues of Mercy, but they knew what they did. I am to dœ
a good turne for them. Let the King haue the Letters I haue
ſent, and repaire thou to me with as much haſt as thou wouldeſt
flye death. I haue words to ſpeake in your eare, will make thee
dumbe, yet are they much too light for the bore of the Matter.

SPEECH.LINE: These good Fellowes will bring thee where I am. Roſincrance
and Guildenſterne, hold their courſe for England. Of them

LINE.ITALIC: I haue much to tell thee, Farewell.
He that thou knoweſt thine,

SPEECH.LINE: Hamlet.
Come, I will giue you way for theſe your Letters,
And do’t the ſpeedier, that you may direƈt me
To him from whom you brought them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Now muſt your conſcience my acquittance ſeal,
And you muſt put me in your heart for Friend,
Sith you haue heard, and with a knowing eare,
That he which hath your Noble Father ſlaine,
Purſued my life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: It well appeares. But tell me,
Why you proceeded not againſt theſe feates,
So crimefull, and ſo Capitall in Nature,
As by your Safety, Wiſedome, all things elſe,
You mainly were ſtirr’d vp?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: O for two ſpeciall Reaſons,
Which may to you (perhaps) ſeeme much vnſinnowed,
And yet to me they are ſtrong. The Queen his Mother,
Liues almoſt by his lookes: and for my ſelfe,
My Vertue or my Plague, be it either which,
She’s ſo coniunƈtiue to my life and ſoule;
That as the Starre moues not but in his Sphere,
I could not but by her. The other Motiue,
Why to a publike count I might not go,
Is the great loue the generall gender beare him,
Who dipping all his Faults in their affeƈtion,
Would like the Spring that turneth Wood to Stone,
Conuert his Gyues to Graces. So that my Arrowes
Too ſlightly timbred for ſo loud a Winde,
Would haue reuerted to my Bow againe,
And not where I had arm’d them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſo haue I a Noble Father loſt,
A Siſter driuen into deſperate tearmes,
Who was (if praiſes may go backe againe)
Stood Challenger on mount of all the Age
For her perfeƈtions. But my reuenge will come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Breake not your ſleepes for that,
You muſt not thinke
That we are made of ſtuffe, ſo flat, and dull,
That we can let our Beard be ſhooke with danger,
And thinke it paſtime. You ſhortly ſhall heare more,
I lou’d your Father, and we loue our Selfe,
And that I hope will teach you to imagine—
How now? What Newes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Letters my Lord from Hamlet, This to your
Maieſty: this to the Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: From Hamlet? Who brought them?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Meſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Saylors my Lord they ſay, I ſaw them not:
They were giuen me by Claudio, he receiu’d them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Lærtes you ſhall heare them:
Leaue vs.

LINE.ITALIC: High and Mighty, you ſhall know I am ſet naked on your
Kingdome. To morrow ſhall I begge leaue to ſee your Kingly
Eyes. When I ſhall (firſt asking your Pardon thereunto) re-
count th’Occaſions of my ſodaine,and more ſtrange returne.

SPEECH.LINE: Hamlet.
What ſhould this meane? Are all the reſt come backe?
Or is it ſome abuſe? Or no ſuch thing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Know you the hand?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis Hamlets Charaƈter, naked and in a Poſt-
ſcript here he ſayes alone: Can you aduiſe me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: I’m loſt in it my Lord; but let him come,
It warmes the very ſickneſſe in my heart,
That I ſhall liue and tell him to his teeth;
Thus diddeſt thou.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: If it be ſo Lærtes, as how ſhould it be ſo:
How otherwiſe will you be rul’d by me?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: If ſo you’l not o’rerule me to a peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: To thine owne peace: if he be now return’d,
As checking at his Voyage, and that he meanes
No more to vndertake it; I will worke him
To an exployt now ripe in my Deuice,
Vnder the which he ſhall not chooſe but fall;
And for his death no winde of blame ſhall breath,
But euen his Mother ſhall vncharge the praƈtice,
And call it accident: Some two Monthes hence
Here was a Gentleman of Normandy,
I’ue ſeene my ſelfe and ſeru’d againſt the French,
And they ran well on Horſebacke; but this Gallant
Had witchcraft in’t; he grew into his Seat,
And to ſuch wondrous doing brought his Horſe,
As had he beene encorps’t and demy-Natur’d
With the braue Beaſt, ſo farre he paſt my thought,
That I in forgery of ſhapes and trickes,
Come ſhort of what he did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: A Norman was’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: A Norman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my life Lamound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: The very ſame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: I know him well, he is the Brooch indeed,
And Iemme of all our Nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Hee mad confeſſion of you,
And gaue you ſuch a Maſterly report,
For Art and exerciſe in your defence;
And for your Rapier moſt eſpecially,
That he cryed out, t’would be a ſight indeed,
If one could match you Sir. This report of his
Did Hamlet ſo envenom with his Enuy,
That he could nothing dœ but wiſh and begge,
Your ſodaine comming ore to play with him;
Now out of this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Why out of this, my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Lærtes was your Father deare to you?
Or are you like the painting of a ſorrow,
A face without a heart?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Why aske you this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Not that I thinke you did not loue your Father,
But that I know Loue is begun by Time:
And that I ſee in paſſages of proofe,
Time qualifies the ſparke and fire of it:
Hamlet comes backe: what would you vndertake,
To ſhow your ſelfe your Fathers ſonne indeed,
More then in words?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: To cut his throat i’th’Church.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: No place indeed ſhould murder Sanƈturize;
Reuenge ſhould haue no bounds: but good Lærtes
Will you dœ this, keepe cloſe within your Chamber,
Hamlet return’d, ſhall know you are come home:
Wee’l put on thoſe ſhall praiſe your excellence,
And ſet a double varniſh on the fame
The Frenchman gaue you, bring you in fine together,
And wager on your heads, he being remiſſe,
Moſt generous, and free from all contriuing,
Will not peruſe the Foiles? So that with eaſe,
Or with a little ſhuffling, you may chooſe
A Sword vnbaited, and in a paſſe of praƈtice,
Requit him for your Father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: I will doo’t.
And for that purpoſe Ile annoint my Sword:
I bought an Vnƈtion of a Mountebanke
So mortall, I but dipt a knife in it,
Where it drawes blood, no Cataplaſme ſo rare,
Colleƈted from all Simples that haue Vertue
Vnder the Moone, can ſaue the thing from death,
That is but ſcratcht withall: Ile touch my point,
With this contagion, that if I gall him ſlightly,
It may be death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s further thinke of this,
Weigh what conuenience both of time and meanes
May fit vs to our ſhape, if this ſhould faile;
And that our drift looke through our bad performance,
’Twere better not aſſaid; therefore this Proieƈt
Should haue a backe or ſecond, that might hold,
If this ſhould blaſt in proofe: Soft, let me ſee
Wee’l make a ſolemne wager on your commings,
I ha’t: when in your motion you are hot and dry,
As make your bowts more violent to the end,
And that he cals for drinke; Ile haue prepar’d him
A Challice for the nonce; whereon but ſipping,
If he by chance eſcape your venom’d ſtuck,
Our purpoſe may hold there; how ſweet Queene.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: One wœ doth tread vpon anothers heele,
So faſt they’l follow: your Siſter’s drown’d Lærtes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Drown’d! O where?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: There is a Willow growes aſlant a Brooke,
That ſhewes his hore leaues in the glaſſie ſtreame:
There with fantaſticke Garlands did ſhe come,
Of Crow-flowers, Nettles, Dayſies, and long Purples,
That liberall Shepheards giue a groſſer name;
But our cold Maids dœ Dead Mens Fingers call them:
There on the pendant boughes, her Coronet weeds
Clambring to hang; an enuious ſliuer broke,
When downe the weedy Trophies, and her ſelfe,
Fell in the weeping Brooke, her cloathes ſpred wide,
And Mermaid-like, a while they bore her vp,
Which time ſhe chaunted ſnatches of old tunes,
As one incapable of her owne diſtreſſe,
Or like a creature Natiue, and indued
Vnto that Element: but long it could not be,
Till that her garments, heauy with her drinke,
Pul’d the poore wretch from her melodious buy,
To muddy death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Alas then, is ſhe drown’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queen.
SPEECH.LINE: Drown’d, drown’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Too much of water haſt thou poore Ophelia,
And therefore I forbid my teares: but yet
It is our tricke, Nature her cuſtome holds,
Let ſhame ſay what it will; when theſe are gone
The woman will be out: Adue my Lord,
I haue a ſpeech of fire,that faine would blaze,
But that this folly doubts it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Let’s follow, Gertrude:
How much I had to dœ to calme his rage?
Now feare I this will giue it ſtart againe;
Therefore let’s follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown.
SPEECH.LINE: Is ſhe to bee buried in Chriſtian buriall, that
wilfully ſeekes her owne ſaluation?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: I tell thee ſhe is, and therefore make her Graue
ſtraight, the Crowner hath ſate on her, and finds it Chri-
ſtian buriall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: How can that be, vnleſſe ſhe drowned her ſelfe in
her owne defence?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ’tis found ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: It muſt be Se offendendo, it cannot bee elſe: for
heere lies the point; If I drowne my ſelfe wittingly, it ar-
gues an Aƈt: and an Aƈt hath three branches. It is an
Aƈt to dœ and to performe; argall ſhe drown’d her ſelfe
wittingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay but heare you Goodman Deluer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me leaue; heere lies the water; good:
heere ſtands the man; good: If the man gœ to this wa-
ter and drowne himſelfe; it is will he nill he, he gœs;
marke you that? But if the water come to him & drowne
him; hee drownes not himſelfe. Argall, hee that is not
guilty of his owne death, ſhortens not his owne life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: But is this law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry is’t, Crowners Queſt Law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you ha the truth on’t: if this had not
beene a Gentlewoman, ſhee ſhould haue beene buried
out of Chriſtian Buriall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why there thou ſay’ſt. And the more pitty that
great folke ſhould haue countenance in this world to
drowne or hang themſelues,more then their euen Chriſti-
an. Come, my Spade; there is no ancient Gentlemen,
but Gardiners, Ditchers and Graue-makers; they hold vp
Adams Profeſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Was he a Gentleman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: He was the firſt that euer bore Armes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Why he had none.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: What, ar’t a Heathen? how doſt thou vnder-
ſtand the Scripture? the Scripture ſayes Adam dig’d;
could hee digge without Armes? Ile put another que-
ſtion to thee; if thou anſwereſt me not to the purpoſe,con-
feſſe thy ſelfe—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Go too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he that builds ſtronger then either the
Maſon, the Shipwright, or the Carpenter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: The Gallowes maker; for that Frame outliues a
thouſand Tenants.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I like thy wit well in good faith, the Gallowes
dœs well; but how dœs it well? it dœs well to thoſe
that dœ ill: now, thou doſt ill to ſay the Gallowes is
built ſtronger then the Church: Argall, the Gallowes
may dœ well to thee. Too’t againe, Come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Who builds ſtronger then a Maſon, a Ship-
wright, or a Carpenter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: I, tell me that, and vnyoake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Marry, now I can tell.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Too’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Other.
SPEECH.LINE: Maſſe, I cannot tell.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Hamlet and Horatio a farre off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Cudgell thy braines no more about it; for your
dull Aſſe will not mend his pace with beating; and when
you are ask’t this queſtion next, ſay a Graue-maker: the
Houſes that he makes, laſts till Doomeſday: go, get thee
to Taughan, fetch me a ſtoupe of Liquor.
In youth when I did loue,did loue,
me thought it was very ſweete:
To contraƈt O the time for a my behoue,
O me thought there was nothing meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ha’s this fellow no feeling of his buſineſſe, that
he ſings at Graue-making?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Cuſtome hath made it in him a property of ea-
sineſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis ee’n ſo; the hand of little Imployment hath
the daintier ſenſe.
But Age with his ſtealing ſteps
hath caught me in his clutch:
And hath ſhipped me intill the Land,
as if I had neuer beene ſuch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That Scull had a tongue in it, and could ſing
once: how the knaue iowles it to th’ grownd, as if it
were Caines Iaw-bone, that did the firſt murther: It
might be the Pateof a Polititian which this Aſſe o’re Of-
fices:one that could circumuent God, might it not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: It might, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Or of a Courtier, which could ſay, Good Mor-
row sweet Lord: how doŒt thou, good Lord? this
might be my Lord ſuch a one, that prais’d my Lord ſuch
a ones HorŒe, when he meant to begge it; might it not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ee’n ſo: and now my Lady Wormes,
Chapleſſe, and knockt about the Mazard with a Sextons
Spade; heere’s fine Reuolution, if wee had the tricke to
see’t. Did theŒe bones coŒt no more the breeding, but
to play at Loggets with ’em? mine ake to thinke
on’t.
A Pickhaxe and a Spade,a Spade,
for and a ſhrowding-Sheete:
O a Pit of Clay for to be made,
for ſuch a GueŒt is meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: There’s another: why might not that bee the
Scull of a Lawyer? where be his Quiddits now? his
Quillets? his CaŒes? his Tenures,and his Tricks? why
