dœ’s he ſuffer this rude knaue now to knocke him about
the Sconce with a dirty Shouell, and will not tell him of
his Aƈtion of Battery? hum. This fellow might be in’s
time a great buyer of Land, with his Statutes,his Recog-
nizances, his Fines,his double Vouchers, his Recoueries:
Is this the fine of his Fines, and the recouery of his Reco-
ueries, to haue his fine Pate full of fine Dirt? will his
Vouchers vouch him no more of his PurchaŒes, and dou-
ble ones too, then the length and breadth of a paire of
Indentures? the very Conueyances of his Lands will
hardly lye in this Boxe; and muſt the Inheritor himſelfe
haue no more? ha?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a iot more,my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Is not Parchment made of Sheep-skinnes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I my Lord, and of Calue-skinnes too.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: They are Sheepe and Calues that ſeek out aſſu-
rance in that. I will ſpeake to this fellow:whoſe Graue’s
this Sir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Mine Sir:

LINE.ITALIC: O a Pit of Clay for to be made,
for ſuch a Gueſt is meete.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I thinke it be thine indeed: for thou lieſt in’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: You lye out on’t Sir, and therefore it is not yours:
for my part, I dœ not lye in’t; and yet it is mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou doſt lye in’t, to be in’t and ſay ’tis thine:
’tis for the dead, not for the quicke, therefore thou
lyeſt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Tis a quicke lye Sir, ’twill away againe from me
to you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What man doſt thou digge it for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: For no man Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What woman then?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: For none neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Who is to be buried in’t?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: One that was a woman Sir; but reſt her Soule,
shee’s dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How abſolute the knaue is? wee muſt ſpeake
by the Carde, or equiuocation will vndœ vs: by the
Lord Horatio, theſe three yeares I haue taken note of it,
the Age is growne ſo picked, that the tœ of the Peſant
comes ſo neere the heeles of our Courtier, hee galls his
Kibe. How long haſt thou been a Graue-maker?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Of all the dayes i’th’yeare, I came too’t that day
that our laſt King Hamlet o’recame Fortinbras.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How long is that ſince?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Cannot you tell that? euery foole can tell that:
It was the very day, that young Hamlet was borne, hee
that was mad,and ſent into England.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I marry, why was he ſent into England?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, becauſe he was mad; hee ſhall recouer his
wits there; or if he do not, it’s no great matter there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twill not be ſeene in him, there the men are as
mad as he.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How came he mad?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Very ſtrangely they ſay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſtrangely?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Faith e’ene with looſing his wits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon what ground?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why heere in Denmarke: I haue bin ſixeteene
heere, man and Boy thirty yeares.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How long will a man lie ’ith’earth ere he rot?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Ifaith,if he be not rotten before he die (as we haue
many po cky Coarſes now adaies, that will ſcarce hold
the laying in) he will laſt you ſome eight yeare, or nine
yeare. A Tanner will laſt you nine yeare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why he, more then another?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Why ſir, his hide is ſo tan’d with his Trade, that
he will keepe out water a great while. And your water,
is a ſore Decayer of your horſon dead body. Heres a Scull
now:this Scul, has laine in the earth three & twenty years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Whoſe was it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A whoreſon mad Fellowes it was;
Whoſe dœ you thinke it was?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, I know not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: A peſtilence on him for a mad Rogue, a pour’d a
Flaggon of Reniſh on my head once. This ſame Scull
Sir, this ſame Scull ſir, was Yoricks Scull, the Kings Ieſter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: This?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: E’ene that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me ſee. Alas poore Yorick, I knew him Ho-
ratio,a fellow of infinite Ieſt; of moſt excellent fancy, he
hath borne me on his backe a thouſand times: And how
abhorred my Imagination is, my gorge riſes at it. Heere
hung thoſe lipps, that I haue kiſt I know not how oft.
Where be your Iibes now? Your Gambals? Your
Songs? Your flaſhes of Merriment that were wont to
set the Table on a Rore? No one now to mock your own
Ieering? Quite chopfalne? Now get you to my Ladies
Chamber, and tell her, let her paint an inch thicke, to this
fauour ſhe muſt come. Make her laugh at that: pry-
thee Horatio tell me one thing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s that my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Doſt thou thinke Alexander lookt o’this fa-
ſhion i’th’earth?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: E’ene ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſmelt ſo? Puh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: E’ene ſo, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: To what baſe vſes we may returne Horatio.
Why may not Imagination trace the Noble duſt of A-
lexander, till he find it ſtopping a bunghole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: ’Twere to conſider: to curiouſly to conſider ſo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No faith, not a iot. But to follow him thether
with modeſtie enough, & likeliehood to lead it; as thus.
Alexander died: Alexander was buried: Alexander re-
turneth into duſt; the duſt is earth; of earth we make
Lome, and why of that Lome (whereto he was conuer-
ted) might they not ſtopp a Beere-barrell?
Imperiall Cæſar, dead and turn’d to clay,
Might ſtop a hole to keepe the winde away.
Oh, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,
Should patch a Wall, t’expell the winters flaw.
But ſoft, but ſoft, aſide; heere comes the King.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: Enter King, Queene, Lærtes, and a Coffin, with Lords attendant
SPEECH.LINE: The Queene, the Courtiers. Who is that they follow,
And with ſuch maimed rites? This doth betoken,
The Coarſe they follow, did with diſperate hand,
Fore do it owne life; ’twas ſome Eſtate.
Couch we a while, and mark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: What Cerimony elſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That is Lærtes, a very Noble youth: Marke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: What Cerimony elſe?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prieſt.
SPEECH.LINE: Her Obſequies haue bin as farre inlarg’d.
As we haue warrantie, her death was doubtfull,
And but that great Command, o’re-ſwaies the order,
She ſhould in ground vnſanƈtified haue lodg’d,
Till the laſt Trumpet. For charitable praier,
Shardes, Flints, and Peebles, ſhould be throwne on her:
Yet heere ſhe is allowed her Virgin Rites,
Her Maiden ſtrewments, and the bringing home
Of Bell and Buriall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Muſt there no more be done ?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prieſt.
SPEECH.LINE: No more be done:
We ſhould prophane the ſeruice of the dead,
To ſing ſage Requiem, and ſuch reſt to her
As to peace-parted Soules.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Lay her i’th’earth,
And from her faire and vnpolluted fleſh,
May Violets ſpring. I tell thee(churliſh Prieſt)
A Miniſtring Angell ſhall my Siſter be,
When thou lieſt howling?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What, the faire Ophelia?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Queene.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweets, to the ſweet farewell.
I hop’d thou ſhould’ſt haue bin my Hamlets wife:
I thought thy Bride-bed to haue deckt (sweet Maid)
And not t’haue ſtrew’d thy Graue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh terrible wœr,
Fall ten times trebble, on that curſed head
Whoſe wicked deed, thy moſt Ingeniousſence
Depriu’d thee of. Hold off the earth a while,
Till I haue caught her once more in mine armes:
Now pile your duſt, vpon the quicke, and dead,
Till of this flat a Mountaine you haue made,
To o’re top old Pelion, or the ſkyiſh head
Of blew Olympus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What is he, whoſe griefes
Beares ſuch an Emphaſis? whoſe phraſe of Sorrow
Coniure the wandring Starres, and makes them ſtand
Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,
Hamlet the Dane.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: The deuill take thy ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou prai’ſt not well,
I prythee take thy fingers from my throat;
Sir though I am not Spleenatiue, and raſh,
Yet haue I ſomething in me dangerous,
Which let thy wiſeneſſe feare. Away thy hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Pluck them aſunder.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Hamlet, Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gen.
SPEECH.LINE: Good my Lord be quiet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I will fight with him vppon this Theme.
Vntill my eielids will no longer wag.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh my Sonne, what Theame?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I lou’d Ophelia; fortie thouſand Brothers
Could not (with all there quantitie of Loue)
Make vp my ſumme. What wilt thou do for her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh he is mad Lærtes,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: For loue of God forbeare him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Come ſhow me what thou’lt dœ.
Woo’t weepe? Woo’t fight? Woo’t teare thy ſelfe?
Woo’t drinke vp Eſile,eate a Crocodile?
Ile doo’t. Doſt thou come heere to whine;
To outface me with leaping in her Graue?
Be buried quicke with her, and ſo will I.
And if thou prate of Mountaines; let them throw
Millions of Akers on vs; till our ground
Sindging his pate againſt the burning Zone,
Make Oſſa like a wart. Nay,and thoul’t mouth,
Ile rant as well as thou.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: This is meere Madneſſe:
And thus awhile the fit will worke on him:
Anon as patient as the female Doue,
When that her Golden Cuplet are diſclos’d;
His ſilence will ſit drooping.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare you Sir:
What is the reaſon that you vſe me thus?
I lou’d you euer; but it is no matter:
Let Hercules himſelfe dœ what he may,
The Cat will Mew, and Dogge will haue his day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you good Horatio wait vpon him,
Strengthen your patience in our laſt nights ſpeech,
Wee’l put the matter to the preſent puſh:
Good Gertrude ſet ſome watch ouer your Sonne,
This Graue ſhall haue a liuing Monument:
An houre of quiet ſhortly ſhall we ſee;
Till then, in patience our proceeding be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: So much for this Sir; now let me ſee the other,
You dœ remember all the Circumſtance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Remember it my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, in my heart there was a kinde of fighting,
That would not let me ſleepe; me thought I lay
Worſe then the mutines in the Bilbœs, raſhly,
(And praiſe be raſhneſſe for it) let vs know,
Our indiſcretion ſometimes ſerues vs well,
When our deare plots do paule, and that ſhould teach vs,
There’s a Diuinity that ſhapes our ends,
Rough-hew them how we will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: That is moſt certaine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Vp from my Cabin
My ſea-gowne ſcarft about me in the darke,
Grop’d I to finde out them; had my deſire,
Finger’d their Packet, and in fine, withdrew
To mine owne roome againe, making ſo bold,
(My feares forgetting manners) to vnſeale
Their grand Commiſſion, where I found Horatio,
Oh royall knauery: An exaƈt command,
Larded with many ſeuerall ſorts of reaſon;
Importing Denmarks health, and Englands too,
With hoo, ſuch Bugges and Goblins in my life,
That on the ſuperuize no leaſure bated,
No not to ſtay the grinding of the Axe,
My head ſhould be ſtruck off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Iſt poſſible?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Here’s the Commiſſion, read it at more leyſure:
But wilt thou heare me how I did proceed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I beſeech you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Being thus benetted round with Villaines,
Ere I could make a Prologue to my braines,
They had begun the Play. I ſate me downe,
Deuis’d a new Commiſſion, wrote it faire,
I once did hold it as our Statiſts dœ,
A baſeneſſe to write faire; and laboured much
How to forget that learning: but Sir now,
It did me Yeomans ſeriuce: wilt thou know
The effeƈts of what I wrote?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: I, good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: An earneſt Coniuration from the King,
As England was his faithfull Tributary,
As loue betweene them, as the Palme ſhould flouriſh,
As Peace ſhould ſtill her wheaten Garland weare,
And ſtand a Comma ’tweene their amities,
And many ſuch like Aſſis of great charge,
That on the view and know of theſe Contents,
Without debatement further, more or leſſe,
He ſhould the bearers put to ſodaine death,
Not ſhriuing time allowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: How was this ſeal’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, euen in that was Heauen ordinate;
I had my fathers Signet in my Purſe,
Which was the Modell of that Daniſh Seale:
Folded the Writ vp in forme of the other,
Subſcrib’d it, gau’t th’impreſſion, plac’t it ſafely,
The changeling neuer knowne: Now, the next day
Was our Sea Fight, and what to this was ſement,
Thou know’ſt already.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: So Guildenſterne and Roſincrance, go too’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Why man, they did make loue to this imployment
They are not neere my Conſcience; their debate
Doth by their owne inſinuation grow:
’Tis dangerous, when the baſer nature comes
Betweene the paſſe, and fell incenſed points
Of mighty oppoſites.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, what a King is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Dœs it not, thinkſt thee, ſtand me now vpon
He that hath kil’d my King, and whor’d my Mother,
Popt in betweene th’eleƈtion and my hopes,
Throwne out his Angle for my proper life,
And with ſuch coozenage; is’t not perfeƈt conſcience,
To quit him with this arme? And is’t not to be damn’d
To let this Canker of our nature come
In further euill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: It muſt be ſhortly knowne to him from England
What is the iſſue of the buſineſſe there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It will be ſhort,
The interim’s mine, and a mans life’s no more
Then to ſay one: but I am very ſorry good Horatio,
That to Lærtes I forgot my ſelfe;
For by the image of my Cauſe, I ſee
The Portraiture of his; Ile count his fauours:
But ſure the brauery of his griefe did put me
Into a Towring paſſion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Peace, who comes heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Your Lordſhip is right welcome back to Denmarke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly thank you Sir, doſt know this waterflie?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: No my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy ſtate is the more gracious; for ’tis a vice to
know him: he hath much Land, and fertile; let a Beaſt
be Lord of Beaſts, and his Crib ſhall ſtand at the Kings
Meſſe; ’tis a Chowgh; but as I ſaw ſpacious in the poſ-
ſeſſion of dirt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Lord, if your friendſhip were at leyſure,
I ſhould impart a thing to you from his Maieſty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I will receiue it with all diligence of ſpirit;put
your Bonet to his right vſe, ’tis for the head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke your Lordſhip, ’tis very hot.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No, beleeue mee ’tis very cold, the winde is
Northerly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: It is indifferent cold my Lord indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Mee thinkes it is very ſoultry, and hot for my
Complexion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Exceedingly, my Lord, it is very ſoultry,as’twere
I cannot tell how: but my Lord,his Maieſty bad me ſig-
nifie to you, that he ha’s laid a great wager on your head:
Sir, this is the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I beſeech you remember.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay,in good faith, for mine eaſe in good faith:
Sir, you are not ignorant of what excellence Lærtes is at
his weapon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What’s his weapon?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Rapier and dagger.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: That’s two of his weapons; but well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſir King ha’s wag’d with him ſix Barbary Hor-
ſes, againſt the which he impon’d as I take it, ſixe French
Rapiers and Poniards, with their aſſignes, as Girdle,
Hangers or ſo: three of the Carriages infaith are very
deare to fancy, very reſponſiue to the hilts, moſt delicate
carriages, and of very liberall conceit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: What call you the Carriages?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: The Carriages Sir, are the hangers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The phraſe would bee more Germaine to the
matter: If we could carry Cannon by our ſides; I would
it might be Hangers till then; but on ſixe Barbary Hor-
ſes againſt ſixe French Swords: their Aſſignes, and three
liberall conceited Carriages, that’s the French but a-
gainſt the Daniſh; why is this impon’d as you call it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: The King Sir,hath laid that in a dozen paſſes be-
tweene you and him, hee ſhall not exceed you three hits;
He hath one twelue for mine, and that would come to
imediate tryall, if your Lordſhip would vouchſafe the
Anſwere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How if I anſwere no?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: I meane my Lord, the oppoſition of your perſon
in tryall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I will walke heere in the Hall; if it pleaſe
his Maieſtie, ’tis the breathing time of day with me; let
the Foyles bee brought, the Gentleman willing, and the
King hold his purpoſe; I will win for him if I can: if
not, Ile gaine nothing but my ſhame, and the odde hits.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I redeliuer you ee’n ſo?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: To this effeƈt Sir, after what flouriſh your na-
ture will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: I commend my duty to your Lordſhip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Yours, yours; hee dſs well to commend it
himſelfe, there are no tongues elſe for’s tongue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: This Lapwing runs away with the ſhell on his
head.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: He did Complie with his Dugge before hee
ſuck’t it: thus had he and mine more of the ſame Beauty
that I know the droſſie age dotes on; only got the tune of
the time, and outward habite of encounter, a kinde of
yeſty colleƈtion, which carries them through & through
the moſt fond and winnowed opinions; and dœ but blow
them to their tryalls: the Bubbles are out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: You will loſe this wager, my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I dœ not thinke ſo, ſince he went into France,
I haue beene in continuall praƈtice; I ſhall winne at the
oddes: but thou wouldeſt not thinke how all heere a-
bout my heart: but it is no matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, good my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: It is but foolery ; but it is ſuch a kinde of
gain-giuing as would perhaps trouble a woman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: If your minde diſlike any thing,obey. I will fore-
ſtall their repaire hither, and ſay you are not fit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Not a whit, we defie Augury; there’s a ſpeciall
Prouidence in the fall of a ſparrow. If it be now, ’tis not
to come: if it bee not to come, it will bee now: if it
be not now; yet it will come; the readineſſe is all, ſince no
man ha’s ought of what he leaues. What is’t to leaue be-
times?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter King, Queene, Lærtes and Lords, with other Atten-dants with Foyles, and Gauntlets, a Table and Flagons of Wine on it

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kin.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Hamlet, come, and take this hand from me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me your pardon Sir, I’ue done you wrong,
But pardon’t as you are a Gentleman.
This preſence knowes,
And you muſt needs haue heard how I am puniſht
With ſore diſtraƈtion? What I haue done
That might your nature honour, and exception
Roughly awake, I heere proclaime was madneſſe:
Was’t Hamlet wrong’d Lærtes? Neuer Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himſelfe be tane away:
And when he’s not himſelfe,do’s wrong Lærtes,
Then Hamlet dœs it not, Hamlet denies it:
Who dœs it then? His Madneſſe? If’t be ſo,
Hamlet is of the Faƈtion that is wrong’d,
His madneſſe is poore Hamlets Enemy.
Sir, in this Audience,
Let my diſclaiming from a purpos’d euill,
Free me ſo farre in your moſt generous thoughts,
That I haue ſhot mine Arrow o’re the houſe,
And hurt my Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſatisfied in Nature,
Whoſe motiue in this caſe ſhould ſtirre me moſt
To my Reuenge. But in my termes of Honor
I ſtand aloofe, and will no reconcilement,
Till by ſome elder Maſters of knowne Honor,
I haue a voyce, and preſident of peace
To keepe my name vngorg’d. But till that time,
I do receiue your offer’d loue like loue,
And wil not wrong it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I do embrace it freely,
And will this Brothers wager frankely play.
Giue vs the Foyles: Come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Come one for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile be your foile Lærtes, in mine ignorance,
Your Skill ſhall like a Starre i’th’darkeſt night,
Sticke fiery off indeede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: You mocke me Sir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: No by this hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue them the Foyles yong Oſricke,
Couſen Hamlet, you know the wager.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Verie well my Lord,
Your Grace hath laide the oddes a’th’weaker ſide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not feare it,
I haue ſeene you both:
But ſince he is better’d, we haue therefore oddes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: This is too heauy,
Let me ſee another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: This likes me well,
Theſe Foyles haue all a length.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſricke.
SPEECH.LINE: I my good Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Set me the Stopes of wine vpon that Table:
If Hamlet giue the firſt, or ſecond hit,
Or quit in anſwer of the third exchange,
Let all the Battlements their Ordinance fire,
The King ſhal drinke to Hamlets better breath,
And in the Cup an vnion ſhal he throw
Richer then that, which foure ſucceſſiue Kings
In Denmarkes Crowne haue worne.
Giue me the Cups,
And let the Kettle to the Trumpets ſpeake,
The Trumpet to the Cannoneer without,
The Cannons to the Heauens, the Heauen to Earth,
Now the King drinkes to Hamlet. Come, begin,
And you the Iudges beare a wary eye.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær
SPEECH.LINE: Come on ſir.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: One.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: No.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Iudgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: A hit, a very palpable hit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Well: againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Stay, giue me drinke.
Hamlet, this Pearle is thine,
Here’s to thy health. Giue him the cup,

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Trumpets ſound, and ſhot gœs off.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile play this bout firſt, ſet by a-while.
Come: Another hit; what ſay you?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: A touch, a touch, I do confeſſe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Our Sonne ſhall win.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: He’s fat, and ſcant of breath.
Heere’s a Napkin, rub thy browes,
The Queene Carowſes to thy fortune, Hamlet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Good Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Gertrude, do not drinke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: I will my Lord;
I pray you pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the poyſon’d Cup, it is too late.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: I dare not drinke yet Madam,
By and by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: Come, let me wipe thy face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, Ile hit him now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: I do not thinke’t.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: And yet ’tis almoſt ’gainſt my conſcience.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Come for the third.
Lærtes, you but dally,
I pray you paſſe with your beſt violence,
I am affear’d you make a wanton of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær
SPEECH.LINE: Say you ſo? Come on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing neither way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue at you now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: Part them, they are incens’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay come, againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Looke to the Queene there hoa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: They bleed on both ſides. How is’t my Lord?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: How is’t Lærtes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: Why as a Woodcocke
To mine Sprindge, Oſricke,
I am iuſtly kill’d with mine owne Treacherie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: How dœs the Queene?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: She ſounds to ſee them bleede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Qu.
SPEECH.LINE: No, no, the drinke, the drinke.
Oh my deere Hamlet, the drinke, the drinke,
I am poyſon’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Oh Villany! How? Let the doore be lock’d.
Treacherie, ſeeke it out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: It is heere Hamlet.
Hamlet, thou art ſlaine,
No Medicine in the world can do thee good.
In thee, there is not halfe an houre of life;
The Treacherous Inſtrument is in thy hand,
Vnbated and envenom’d: the foule praƈtiſe
Hath turn’d it ſelfe on me. Lœ, heere I lye,
Neuer to riſe againe: Thy Mothers poyſon’d:
I can no more, the King, the King’s too blame.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: The point envenom’d too,
Then venome to thy worke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: All.
SPEECH.LINE: Treaſon, Treaſon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: King.
SPEECH.LINE: O yet defend me Friends, I am but hurt.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere thou inceſtuous, murdrous,
Damned Dane,
Drinke off this Potion: Is thy Vnion heere?
Follow my Mother.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lær.
SPEECH.LINE: He is iuſtly ſeru’d.
It is a poyſon temp’red by himſelfe:
Exchange forgiueneſſe with me, Noble Hamlet;
Mine and my Fathers death come not vpon thee,
Nor thine on me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: Heauen make thee free of it, I follow thee.
I am dead Horatio, wretched Queene adiew,
You that looke pale,and tremble at this chance,
That are but Mutes or audience to this aƈte:
Had I but time (as this fell Sergeant death
Is ſtrick’d in his Arreſt) oh I could tell you.
But let it be: Horatio, I am dead,
Thou liu’ſt, report me and my cauſes right
To the vnſatisfied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Neuer beleeue it.
I am more an Antike Roman then a Dane:
Heere’s yet ſome Liquor left.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: As th’art a man, giue me the Cup.
Let go, by Heauen Ile haue’t.
Oh good Horatio, what a wounded name,
(Things ſtanding thus vnknowne) ſhall liue behind me.
If thou did’ſt euer hold me in thy heart,
Abſent thee from felicitie awhile,
And in this harſh world draw thy breath in paine,
To tell my Storie.
SPEECH.STAGEDIR: March afarre off, and ſhout within.
SPEECH.LINE: What warlike noyſe is this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Oſr.
SPEECH.LINE: Yong Fortinbras, with conqueſt come frō Poland
To th’Ambaſſadors of England giues this warlike volly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ham.
SPEECH.LINE: O I dye Horatio:
The potent poyſon quite ore-crowes my ſpirit,
I cannot liue to heare the Newes from England,
But I do propheſie th’eleƈtion lights
On Fortinbras, he ha’s my dying voyce,
So tell him with the occurrents more and leſſe,
Which haue ſolicited. The reſt is ſilence. O, o, o, o.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hora.
SPEECH.LINE: Now cracke a Noble heart:
Goodnight ſweet Prince,
And flights of Angels ſing thee to thy reſt,
Why do’s the Drumme come hither?

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Fortinbras and Engliſh Ambaſſador, with Drumme, Colours, and Attendants

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fortin.
SPEECH.LINE: Where is this ſight?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: What is it ye would ſee;
If ought of wœ, or wonder, ceaſe your ſearch.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: His quarry cries on hauocke. Oh proud death,
What feaſt is toward in thine eternall Cell.
That thou ſo many Princes, at a ſhoote,
So bloodily haſt ſtrooke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Amb.
SPEECH.LINE: The ſight is diſmall,
And our affaires from England come too late,
The eares are ſenſeleſſe that ſhould giue vs hearing,
To tell him his command’ment is fulfill’d,
That Roſincrance and Guildenſterne are dead:
Where ſhould we haue our thankes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Not from his mouth,
Had it th’abilitie of life to thanke you:
He neuer gaue command’ment for their death.
But ſince ſo iumpe vpon this bloodie queſtion,
You from the Polake warres, and you from England
Are heere arriued. Giue order that theſe bodies
High on a ſtage be placed to the view,
And let me ſpeake to th’yet vnknowing world,
How theſe things came about. So ſhall you heare
Of carnall, bloudie, and vnnaturall aƈts,
Of accidentall iudgements, caſuall ſlaughters
Of death’s put on by cunning, and forc’d cauſe,
And in this vpſhot, purpoſes miſtooke,
Falne on the Inuentors head. All this can I
Truly deliuer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Let vs haſt to heare it,
And call the Nobleſt to the Audience.
For me, with ſorrow, I embrace my Fortune,
I haue ſome Rites of memory in this Kingdome,
Which are to claime, my vantage doth
Inuite me,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hor.
SPEECH.LINE: Of that I ſhall haue alwayes cauſe to ſpeake,
And from his mouth
Whoſe voyce will draw on more:
But let this ſame be preſently perform’d,
Euen whiles mens mindes are wilde,
Leſt more miſchance
On plots, and errors happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: For.
SPEECH.LINE: Let foure Captaines
Beare Hamlet like a Soldier to the Stage,
For he was likely, had he beene put on
To haue prou’d moſt royally:
And for his paſſage,
The Souldiours Muſicke,and the rites of Warre
Speake lowdly for him.
Take vp the body; Such a ſight as this
Becomes the Field, but heere ſhewes much amis.
Go, bid the Souldiers ſhoote.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Exeunt Marching: after the which, a Peale of Ordenance are ſhot off
